____________________________________________________________

Phelps' determination legendary

Autor: Leicht, Linda.

Información de publicación: Springfield News Leader ; Springfield, Mo. [Springfield, Mo]. 19 June 2011.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/phelps-determination-legendary/docview/1542098785/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: The recently married couple chose Springfield as their home, bringing a "hearty spirit" to the pioneer settlement.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Phelps%27+determination+legendary&amp;author=Leicht%2C+Linda&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2011-06-19&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Springfield+News+Leader&amp;issn=0893-3448&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anorthcentralnews_

Texto completo:   News-Leader
Mary Whitney Phelps began her life in Maine, the daughter of a sea captain.
She was orphaned, perhaps divorced, and then married a young lawyer named John S. Phelps who would someday be governor of Missouri.
The recently married couple chose Springfield as their home, bringing a "hearty spirit" to the pioneer settlement. It was 1837, and Springfield consisted of 14 families and a few log cabins. Mary had another one built while John was away on business, according to a biographical sketch in "History of Greene County, Missouri," printed in 1883, five years after her death from pneumonia.
That story reveals a determination and ingenuity that would continue to be part of Mary's life, including during the Civil War.
The Phelpses sided with the Union, but owned slaves who worked on their farm.
After the Battle of Wilson's Creek, John, a congressman at the time, enlisted as a private in the Missouri Infantry -- although he was later promoted to lieutenant colonel. He escorted several hundred citizens and sick soldiers to Rolla while Mary stayed home to feed the Union soldiers who remained in Springfield.
A building Phelps owned was used as headquarters for Gen. Nathaniel Lyon, leader of the Union troops at Wilson's Creek, where Lyon was killed. Her daughter later recalled that the night before the battle, Lyon told Mary he expected to be killed, adding, "I beg you to take care of my body."
That is what she did. Although there were stories that credited her with rescuing Lyon's body from the battlefield, she would later tell the story slightly differently.
Writing from Oregon, Mary sent a letter to the Springfield Advertiser setting the record straight. The general's body had been moved to his headquarters -- the house owned by the Phelpses -- and Mary eventually had it taken to her farm where she cleaned it and covered it until a casket was made.
While there, Gen. Sterling Price's Confederate troops came to the house, where Mary stood by the corpse until 4 a.m. when Price offered a guard. The body remained at her home until Lyon's relatives came to take it back to his native Connecticut for burial.
The Phelps home, in the meantime, became a hospital -- like many other homes. But Mary managed to move all the Confederate wounded to houses of southern sympathizers and filled hers with Union wounded.
A letter written by Mary to a nephew in New York says, "The rebels have taken our county, and especially our farm and our town property. They have ... stolen everything living, horses & cattle & grain..."
While John and daughter Mary Ann were in St. Louis, Mary stayed in Springfield, determined to "keep the Devils out of our dwelling."
Mary's determination is legend. One story has her rescuing George, one of her slaves, who had been tied to a tree in town by Confederates. She demanded that he -- and horses and a wagon -- be released, and stayed there all night until the colonel in charge let them go.
The next spring John and their son, John E., fought at the Battle of Pea Ridge in northwest Arkansas. As she did at Wilson's Creek, Mary helped care for the wounded on the battlefield.
In honor of those efforts, Mary was given a $20,000 grant from Congress. She used the money to support an orphanage for children of both sides of the conflict.
She also turned her attention to a new cause -- women's suffrage, serving next to Susan B. Anthony as a vice president of the National Woman Suffrage Convention.
ID_Code: DO-103310003

Materia: American Civil War

Lugar: Missouri Maine

Título: Phelps' determination legendary

Autor: Leicht, Linda

Título de publicación: Springfield News Leader; Springfield, Mo.

Año de publicación: 2011

Fecha de publicación: Jun 19, 2011

Sección: NEWS

Editorial: Gannett Media Corp

Lugar de publicación: Springfield, Mo.

País de publicación: United States, Springfield, Mo.

Materia de publicación: General Interest Periodicals--United States

ISSN: 08933448

Tipo de fuente: Periódicos

Idioma de la publicación: English

Tipo de documento: News

ID del documento de ProQuest: 1542098785

URL del documento: https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/phelps-determination-legendary/docview/1542098785/se-2?accountid=14708

Última actualización: 2017-11-21

____________________________________________________________

Dexter Tigers' title turns team's tears into triumph

Autor: Neff, Andrew.

Información de publicación: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]. 15 June 2011.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/dexter-tigers-title-turns-teams-tears-into/docview/2229247481/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Dexter+Tigers%27+title+turns+team%27s+tears+into+triumph&amp;author=Neff%2C+Andrew&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2011-06-15&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;issn=0892-8738&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: BREWER -- Tears of sorrow were at least temporarily replaced by tears of joy Wednesday night as the Dexter High School softball team gave its grieving town something to cheer about.
"We had to decide yesterday if we wanted to play today or Thursday, and we all decided we wanted to play today because we knew we needed something positive in our community," said senior Devyn Bell, one of Wednesday's Eastern Maine Class C championship game heroines. "Everything happening right now is just so negative, it's hard and we played in honor of the Lake family."
The Lake family refers to Amy Lake and children Coty and Monica, who were all shot to death by estranged husband and father Steven Lake on Monday before Steven Lake killed himself.
Bell went 3-for-3 with two doubles, a single, and two RBIs and her top-seeded Tigers survived a last at-bat rally by No. 3 Central of Corinth and edged the Red Devils 5-4 at Coffin Field.
The 17-2 Tigers will play West champ Telstar in a game moved from noon to 7 p.m. at Coffin Saturday so team members can attend the funeral for the Lakes.
Each member of the Tigers had some degree of personal experience, familiarity or involvement with the Lakes.
"Everyone knew the kids. Monica was a softball player herself and I coached her with her mother in rec field hockey, and my younger brother had Mrs. Lake as a teacher," said Bell. "It's really hit home to everyone on this team."
After Central took a 1-0 lead on Kayla Grindle's one-out RBI groundout in the third inning, Bell tied it with a one-out, RBI single to left. Jordyn Bell then made it 2-1 Tigers with an RBI groundout, and Harley Ponte followed with an RBI single through the left infield hole in the bottom of the fourth.
The 15-4 Devils got a run back in the fifth as Brianna Speed hit a leadoff single and scored on a one-out single to right by Roberta Trafton, but Dexter scored twice more in the bottom of the inning. Maicee Gustin reached second on a dropped ball in the outfield and scored on another Devyn Bell double to center, and Bell scored on Jordyn Bell's single over the third baseman's head.
"I think one of the big things was when we were behind 4-2 and had two outs and then made an error, and they scored two more runs. That really hurt," said Central coach Durice Washburn.
Central would threaten in the sixth and fail to score, but then put Dexter starting pitcher Libby Kain in a jam in the seventh as the first three batters reached to load the bases. After a flyout to center, two runs scored on a groundout to short and some aggressive baserunning by the appropriately named Speed and Katie Blanchard. But Chrissy Cunningham got the last out with a running catch of a shallow fly ball in right to touch off a celebration.
Libby Kain, who knew the Lakes, credited her ability to change speeds for limiting Central's potent offense to eight hits.
"That was a pretty typical game for her," said Dexter coach Galen Chapman. "She may have one or two innings where she has control trouble, but she's pretty steady."
Kain said it's the first time in days she has felt like smiling.
"My family was really good friends with them, and when I heard the news, I couldn't believe it. It just didn't seem real," Kain said. "We decided we were going to play for them and dedicate this game to them. It definitely felt good to put our minds on something else."
The two teams met before the game to exchange symbolic tokens.
"They gave us purple ribbons and we gave them flowers with little notes saying how sorry we were for the tragedy," Washburn said.
The title was the first in Class C for Dexter's program.
"I'm just so proud of the girls. They fought through this and stayed focused," Chapman said. "This is the first time we've won anything like this in Class C. We've won in Class B, but our last one was in 1984 or 1985.
"Ironically, they (Central) beat us in 2004 and that's the last time we've been this far."
The game featured several outstanding defensive plays, one of the best being a perfectly executed relay from center fielder Blanchard to shortstop Speed to catcher Roberta Trafton, who tagged out Lauren Crane at the plate in the first on an Eva Wing double.
Credit: Andrew Neff BDN Staff

Materia: Lakes; Softball

Lugar: Maine

____________________________________________________________

Mom held in death of 6-year-old boy

Autor: Tuohy, Lynne; Lavoie, Denise.

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 14 June 2011: A.9.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mom-held-death-6-year-old-boy/docview/2571481164/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Mom+held+in+death+of+6-year-old+boy&amp;author=Tuohy%2C+Lynne%3BLavoie%2C+Denise&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.9&amp;date=2011-06-14&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. Even as her son's image was plastered across TV and computer screens nationwide while authorities worked to identify the little boy found dead along a dirt road in Maine, his mother called his Texas school daily to report his absence.
Julianne McCrery, 42, of Irving, was ordered held without bail Thursday on second-degree murder charges in New Hampshire, where she made her initial court appearance in the death of her son, 6-year-old Camden, after waiving extradition from Massachusetts.
Information offered by authorities and friends paint a portrait of a loving but troubled mother who suffered from mood swings that sometimes culminated in road trips but she'd always come back.
This time, after one such trip to New England, she won't be returning to Texas anytime soon.
A lawyer representing McCrery at a brief hearing in Massachusetts said that judging by conversations with his client, he thinks she traveled hundreds of miles from home with the idea of taking her son's life and committing suicide.
I believe she was up here to bring both herself and her son to heaven, George Murphy said in Concord, Mass. She told me, 'I love my son very much. I know where he is. He's in heaven. I want to go there as soon as possible.'
The boy's body was found Saturday in an isolated area in South Berwick, Maine, and state police were at a loss to identify him because no one had reported him missing.
The last day the boy attended school in Texas was Friday, May 6. The next Monday, his mother called to report he was absent because he was ill. She continued to call this week, saying he was still sick.
McCrery was detained Wednesday at a highway rest stop in Chelmsford, Mass., after police got a tip about her pickup, which matched a vehicle seen near the spot where the boy's body was found covered with a blanket.

Network of animal lovers helps dog find new Mass. home

Autor: Roose-Church, Lisa.

Información de publicación: Livingston County Daily Press & Argus ; Howell, Mich. [Howell, Mich]. 12 June 2011.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/network-animal-lovers-helps-dog-find-new-mass/docview/1545339087/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: ON THE WEB Livingston County Animal Control: www.livingstonlive.org/LCAC New England Lab Rescue: www.newenglandlabrescue.com Pilots N Paws: www.pilotsnpaws.\n

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Network+of+animal+lovers+helps+dog+find+new+Mass.+home&amp;author=Roose-Church%2C+Lisa&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2011-06-12&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Livingston+County+Daily+Press+%26+Argus&amp;issn=2150-5667&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Amidwestnews1_

Texto completo:   An intricate network of animal lovers in Livingston County and Maine interested in helping stray, abandoned or unwanted animals has helped give a new home to a giant Schnauzer.
The giant Schnauzer, Mitzie, was flown by volunteers with Pilots N Paws to Columbus, Ohio, and then to Massachusetts, where a family who recently lost a dog wants to adopt her.
"She will live out the rest of her life loved on a farm with a family," said Kristen Carney, rescue and adoption coordinator with New England Lab Rescue in Limerick, Maine. "I'm really excited. ... That's why we do this. We just saved an animal that otherwise might have been put to sleep."
Debbie Oberle, director of Livingston County Animal Control, said Mitzie was placed at the Livingston County facility by family members of her elderly owners after one owner died and the other was unable to care for her.
New England Lab Rescue, which typically rescues Labadors or Lab mixes, saw Mitzie online and thought it could help even though she is not a Lab.
Carney said volunteers at her organization saw the description for Mitzie and the story about her owners. It read that the 10-year-old dog was a "very sweet girl, housebroken, good with cats and dogs."
The local posting also noted that Mitzie needs surgery because her eyes are glued shut with exudates and hair. While Livingston County Animal Control was able to clip her hair mats, Mitzie's eyelids are raw and she has severe entropion on both lower eyelids, which means her eyelashes grow inward.
The cost of that surgery did not deter New England Lab Rescue, which agreed to pay for the surgery, Oberle said.
"It spoke to us," Carney said about Mitzie's story. "If you think of those two elderly owners, they would have been horrified to think (Mitzie) would be put to sleep," Carney said. "No one would want her at 10, and we thought we'd give it a try. ... We posted it to our Facebook page and a couple people were immediately interested."
Among those interested was a couple who live on a farm in western Massachusetts. They recently lost their giant Schnauzer and were looking for a new one when they saw Mitzie's photograph.
A flurry of phone calls between Livingston County Animal Control and New England Lab Rescue included a third group -- Pilots N Paws, which partners pilots and plane owners willing to assist with the transportation of animals and rescue groups that place strays or unwanted animals with families.
The end result is that a Pilots N Paws pilot flew Mitzie to a foster home in Ohio on Wednesday where she spent the night with a foster mom before getting into a car with another volunteer who has a planned vacation in New England and volunteered to drive Mitzie to her new home.
"The Livingston (Animal Control) is excellent," Carney said. "They care enough to take (Mitzie) to the groomer because she was so uncomfortable with all her hair. They were willing to work with the pilot and us. Some shelters, it's nothing but trouble and pain to work with. The Livingston shelter was not that way."
Contact Daily Press & Argus reporter Lisa Roose-Church at (517) 552-2846 or at lrchurch@gannett.com.

Pilots N Paws: www.pilotsnpaws.org

Coffee Break / Gift shop for Tiger fans sold

Información de publicación: The Commercial Appeal ; Memphis, Tenn. [Memphis, Tenn]. 10 June 2011: C.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/coffee-break-gift-shop-tiger-fans-sold/docview/2594964689/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Coffee+Break+%2F+Gift+shop+for+Tiger+fans+sold&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.1&amp;date=2011-06-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Commercial+Appeal&amp;issn=0745-4856&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Tiger Gift Shop at 549 S. Highland has been sold to the stores manager, Jeremy Stinson, and his wife, Tonia.
The Stinsons also bought the rights to Tiger Basketball and tigergiftshop.net, Mike Bowen, president and CEO of Champion Awards and Apparel, said Thursday.
Champion, the largest and longest local licensee for the University of Memphis, will keep a close relationship to Stinson and his store, Bowen said.
Bowen and his wife, Suzie, founded Tiger Gift Shop in 2007.
Norris to speak to NFIB
The Memphis Area Action Council, the local arm of the National Federation of Independent Business , will host a Legislative Review forum featuring state Senate Majority Leader Mark Norris from 11:30 a.m.-1 p.m. on Wednesday at Regions Bank, 6200 Poplar.
The free program includes lunch, but registration is required. Deadline is Monday . Call (615) 872-5331 or e-mail valerie.nagoshiner@nfib.org.
Verso joins Maine effort
Memphis-based Verso Paper Corp. has joined a partnership with Time Inc., Hearst Enterprises, National Geographic, the Sustainable Forestry Initiative and other forest products companies to promote sustainable forest management principles and initiatives in Maine.
Its an extension of a pilot project that last year protected about 620,000 acres in the state.
Learn more at versopaper.com.
Cadence gives to Habitat
Cadence Bank Memphis has pledged $60,000 to Habitat for Humanity of Greater Memphis to help fund the operations of the organizations new Habitat ReStore.
The first $20,000 payment of the three-year pledge from Cadence will be made today at Habitat for Humanitys Memphis office at 7136 Winchester.
Cadence is looking to focus its community efforts on affordable housing and economic development in Memphis, and this is a way we can have a positive impact on affordable housing here, said Bill Stemmler, vice president and community development officer.
He said Cadence is donating the money to the Habitat ReStore to help the organization devote its ReStore profits to building houses instead of overhead expenses.
Cadence Bank NA is owned by Houston-based Community Bancorp LLC.
Done deals
The 58,000-square-foot bank and office office building at 158 Madison has been sold by Colorado-based Chiti LLC to Canadian-based 158 Madison LLC for $1,025,000. Regions Bank and Memphis Minority Business Council have long-term leases there. Other space, from individual offices to full floors, are available for lease. Brian Califf with NAI Saig Company negotiated the deal.
Dinks Restaurant, which will feature a do-it-yourself hamburger bar, has signed a five-year lease for two retail bays at Poplar Market Shopping Center at 890 W. U.S. 72 in Collierville. Gary Shanks Jr. with The Shopping Center Group represented the landlord, Premier Management Co. Tucker Beck of Crye-Leike Commercial represented the tenant, Scott and Tracy Dinkins, doing business as Moo Loo Holdings LLC.

Man to be in Maine court on manslaughter charge

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 09 June 2011: 3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/man-be-maine-court-on-manslaughter-charge/docview/1317093958/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: A 21-year-old southern New Jersey man faces charges of interfering with transportation for allegedly shining a laser pointer at the crew of a Coast Guard helicopter conducting rescue training off Ocean City.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Man+to+be+in+Maine+court+on+manslaughter+charge&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=3&amp;date=2011-06-09&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo:   REGION BRIEFS
Man makes Maine court appearance
AUGUSTA, Maine: A 23-year-old man charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a friend was scheduled to make his initial court appearance in Maine.
Ryan Ouimet, of Colts Neck, was scheduled to appear Wednesday afternoon in Franklin County Superior Court in Farmington. He is charged in the death of 23-year-old Andrew Holland, of Cape Elizabeth.
Ouimet and Holland were friends who graduated last month from the University of Maine at Farmington and were working this summer as cooks at the Old Post Office Caf in nearby Mount Vernon.
The shooting took place about 10:30 p.m. May 31 when a handgun owned by Ouimet went off inside a friend's High Street apartment in Farmington, near the university.
Associated Press
Services held for girl killed at park
ATLANTIC CITY: An 11-year-old New Jersey girl who died after falling from a Ferris wheel has been laid to rest following a funeral service in Atlantic City. More than 350 mourners gathered Wednesday at the All Wars Memorial Building for the 30-minute Muslim service for Abiah Jones of Pleasantville.
The Press of Atlantic City reports that friends and classmates from Pleasant Tech Academy Charter School wore T-shirts with her picture and the slogan "RIP. Love You."
Jones was buried at Seaside Cemetery in Upper Township.
Authorities say she was riding alone in one of the Ferris wheel's gondolas when she plunged about 100 feet from the ride at Morey's Mariner's Landing Pier in Wildwood on Friday.
Associated Press
Hearings on WNET deal begin today
TRENTON: Lawmakers begin hearings today examining the state's deal with WNET that puts the New York public television station in charge of a rebranded New Jersey Network.
Though the Legislature has not yet formally received details of the deal, the Assembly Budget Committee will meet at 10 a.m. in the Statehouse Annex to solicit testimony from invited guests.
Gov. Chris Christie announced details of the WNET deal Monday. The station, through a new nonprofit governed by New Jersey citizens, will rebrand NJN as NJTV, add improved PBS programs and provide New Jersey-focused programs in conjunction with Caucus Educational Corp. It will air a nightly news show as part of a required 20 hours a week of New Jersey-focused programming.
Assemblyman Louis Greenwald, D-Camden, the budget committee chairman, said his main goal has been to continue New Jersey-centric programming and ensure a smooth transition.
"Ensuring employees received equitable and fair consideration was also vital, and I'm not convinced that's happening under this proposal," Greenwald said.
No decisions have been made about retaining NJN employees or programs, WNET president Neal Shapiro said.
Assembly Minority Leader Alex DeCroce, R-Morris, said the deal unburdens taxpayers and sustains public television in New Jersey for the long run.
Last year, NJN had $28.8 million in expenses and $17.6 million in revenues. The state provided $11.2 million to fill the gap.
A Senate committee will hold a similar hearing after the plan is submitted to the Legislature next week. Lawmakers will have until June 28 to veto the deal.
New Jersey also plans to sell its nine public radio stations for $1.926 million cash and $2.412 million in noncash contributions.
Michael Symons
Cops: Man pointed laser at helicopter
ATLANTIC CITY: A 21-year-old southern New Jersey man faces charges of interfering with transportation for allegedly shining a laser pointer at the crew of a Coast Guard helicopter conducting rescue training off Ocean City.
Eric J. Bouda of Mantua was arrested Tuesday night by Ocean City police.
The incident occurred shortly after 9 p.m. Tuesday while a Coast Guard helicopter from the Atlantic City air station was conducting rescue training maneuvers with the crew of a commercial tow boat service.
"Educating the public on how detrimental lasers can be to our air crews is key," said Capt. Nicholas Bartolotta, commanding officer of the Coast Guard's Air Station Atlantic City.
"Pointing lasers at aircraft jeopardizes the safety of the Coast Guard and commercial airliners and needs to be stopped."
Associated Press

Boxing
Fight Schedule
Friday
At Roseland Ballroom, New York (ESPN2), Kenny Galarza vs. Irving Garcia, 10, welterweights; Thomas Dulorme vs. DeMarcus Corley, 10, welterweights.
At Mendoza, Argentina, Jean Piero Perez vs. Juan Carlos Reveco, 12, for the interim WBA World flyweight title.
At Chumash Casino, Santa Ynez, Calif. (SHO), Lateef Kayode vs. Matt Godfrey, 10, cruiserweights; Chros Avalos vs. Khabir Suleymanov, 10, super bantamweights.
Saturday
At Roseland Ballroom, New York (SHO), Hector Sanchez vs. Vincent Arroyo, 10, junior welterweights; Luis Del Valle vs. Dat Nguyen, 10, featherweights.
At TBA, Mexico, Austin Trout vs. David Lopez, 12, for Trout's WBA World light middleweight title.

Transactions
BASEBALL
MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL Suspended Washington RHP Jason Marquis five games, Arizona RHP Esmerling Vasquez three games and Washington manager Jim Riggleman and Arizona manager Kirk Gibson one game each and fined them undisclosed amounts for throwing at hitters after both teams had been warned during a June 5 game. Suspended Boston RHP Jonathan Papelbon three games for making contact with an umpire during a June 4 game against Oakland.
American League
BOSTON RED SOX Activated SS Marco Scutaro from the 15-day DL. Sent RHP Scott Atchison to Pawtucket (IL).
CLEVELAND INDIANS Released INF Wes Hodges.
OAKLAND ATHLETICS Placed LHP Brett Anderson and 2B Mark Ellis on the 15-day DL. Selected the contract of INF Jemile Weeks and recalled LHP Bobby Cramer from Sacramento (PCL). Transferred LHP Dallas Braden to the 60-day DL.
National League
CINCINNATI REDS Recalled RHP Edinson Volquez from Louisville (IL). Optioned RHP Daryl Thompson to Louisville.
COLORADO ROCKIES Placed OF Dexter Fowler on the 15-day DL. Purchased the contract of OF Charlie Blackmon from Colorado Springs (PCL).
PITTSBURGH PIRATES Designated RHP Jose Ascanio for assignment. Recalled LHP Tony Watson from Indianapolis (IL).
North American League
SAN ANGELO COLTS Signed INF Eddie Browne and LHP Cory Patton.
BASKETBALL
National Basketball Association
BOSTON CELTICS Announced G Ray Allen exercised his 2011-12 contract option.
NEW ORLEANS HORNETS Announced the resignation of assistant coach Mike Malone to become an assistant coach with Golden State.
FOOTBALL
CFL
EDMONTON ESKIMOS Signed QB Eric Ward.
WINNIPEG BLUE BOMBERS Signed DB Andre Jones.
UFL
SACRAMENTO MOUNTAIN LIONS Removed QB Jeff Mroz from the reserve-unsigned list. Added RB John David Washington to the active roster.
VIRGINIA DESTROYERS Added RB Clifton Smith to the active roster.
HOCKEY
NHL
NHL Suspended Vancouver D Aaron Rome four games for his blindside hit on Boston F Nathan Horton during Monday's game.
CAROLINA HURRICANES Named Rod Brind'Amour and Dave Lewis assistant coaches, Ron Francis director of hockey operations and Tom Rowe pro scout.
COLUMBUS BLUE JACKETS Announced the contracts of assistant general manager Don Boyd and director of pro scouting Bob Strumm will not be renewed.
COLLEGE
AUBURN Named Eysha Ambler assistant volleyball coach.
BUFFALO Announced sophomore men's basketball F Will Regan is transferring from Virginia.
CONCORDIA (TEXAS) Named Link Scoggins men's assistant soccer coach.
MARQUETTE Named John Barnereps women's assistant basketball coach.
MUHLENBERG Announced the resignation of wrestling coach Mike Kocsis.
NEW MEXICO Named Lee De Leon associate athletic director for development.
OHIO STATE Announced senior QB Terrelle Pryor will not play this season.
TENNESSEE Announced the resignation of athletic director Mike Hamilton, effective at the end of June.
TEXAS A&M Named Kyle Keller assistant basketball coach.

BASEBALL
American League
BOSTON RED SOX Activated RHP John Lackey from the 15-day DL. Optioned OF Josh Reddick to Pawtucket (IL).
CHICAGO WHITE SOX Activated 3B Mark Teahen from the 15-day DL. Designated RHP Jeff Marquez for assignment.
DETROIT TIGERS Placed LHP David Purcey on the paternity leave list. Recalled LHP Adam Wilk from Toledo (IL).
National League
COLORADO ROCKIES Placed RHP Matt Daley on the 15-day DL. Recalled LHP Rex Brothers from Colorado Springs (PCL).
SAN FRANCISCO GIANTS Placed INF Brandon Belt on the 15-day DL. Recalled INF Conor Gillaspie from Fresno (PCL).

____________________________________________________________

An al-lure-ing new trend

Autor: Bonner, Jessie L.

Información de publicación: Montgomery Advertiser ; Montgomery, Ala. [Montgomery, Ala]. 06 June 2011.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/al-lure-ing-new-trend/docview/1223718595/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Nationwide, supplies at fly fishing shops from the coasts of Maine to landlocked Idaho are running out. At Whiting Farms, Inc., in western Colorado, one of the world's largest producers of fly tying feathers, the roosters live about a year while their saddle feathers -- the ones on the bird's backside and the most popular for hair extensions -- grow as long as possible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=An+al-lure-ing+new+trend&amp;author=Bonner%2C+Jessie+L&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2011-06-06&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Montgomery+Advertiser&amp;issn=0892-4457&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo:   BOISE, Idaho -- For a 49-year-old manager of a fly fishing shop, Jim Bernstein spends an awful lot of time on the phone with hairdressers.
They bought out his display of hackles -- the long, skinny rooster feathers fishermen use to make lures -- months ago. But the calls keep coming at Eldredge Bros. Fly Shop in Maine, and the women keep asking for more supplies as they fight to keep up with the latest hair trend: Feather extensions.
Nationwide, supplies at fly fishing shops from the coasts of Maine to landlocked Idaho are running out. Some hairdressers have gotten desperate to follow the craze that was fueled, in part, by "American Idol" judge and rocker Steven Tyler, who began wearing the feathers in his long hair.
"I've taught hairdressers over the phone how we dye the feathers so they can buy the un-dyed kind and dye them themselves," Bernstein said.
Some feathers sold online are fetching hundreds of dollars more than the usual prices.
"I'm looking around the shop thinking, 'Hmmm, what else can they put in their hair?'" Bernstein said
Fly fishermen are not happy, bemoaning the trend in online message boards and sneering at so-called "feather ladies."
"It takes years and years and years to develop these chickens to grow these feathers. And now, instead of ending up on a fly, it's going into women's hair," said Matt Brower, a guide and assistant manager at Idaho Angler in Boise.
"I think that's the reason a lot of people are a little peeved about it," he said.
The feathers are not easy to come by in the first place.
They come from roosters that are genetically bred and raised for their plumage. In most cases, the birds do not survive the plucking.
At Whiting Farms, Inc., in western Colorado, one of the world's largest producers of fly tying feathers, the roosters live about a year while their saddle feathers -- the ones on the bird's backside and the most popular for hair extensions -- grow as long as possible. Then the animal is euthanized.
As hair extensions, the feathers can be brushed, blow dried, straightened and curled once they are snapped into place. Most salons sell the feather strands for $5 to $10 a piece. The trend has become so popular a company online even sells feather extensions for dogs.
The craze has also left hairstylists scrambling to find rooster saddle feathers, as fly shops hold onto a select few for their regular customers. The businesses will now ask if the feathers are for hairdressing, said Shelley Ambroz, who owns MiraBella Salon and Spa in Boise.
"If you go in and you're a woman, they won't sell to you," said Ambroz, who started to eye her husband's fly fishing gear after stores ran out.
"He told me to stay out of his feathers," she said.
Whiting Farms is harvesting about 1,500 birds a week for their feathers and still can't keep up with its current orders, said owner and founder Tom Whiting, a poultry geneticist. The company has stopped taking on new accounts.
"I've tried to withhold some for the fly fishing world because when the fashion trend goes away, which it will, I've still got to make a living," he said.
The company was the one that told Bernstein in Maine several months ago that rooster saddle feathers had somehow become the latest coveted hair accessory. Bernstein said he scoffed at the notion that it could reach his shop along the coast of southern Maine.
"This is Maine, it's not California. We're a little behind the trends here," he said. "I screwed up. I should have said: 'Send me everything you've got.'"
Bernstein's inventory of rooster saddle feathers has long been depleted. About three weeks ago, he dusted off a rooster neck with feathers that had been set aside for fly tying classes at the shop. The neck would have normally cost $29.95, but the shop sold it for $360.
It's not uncommon to find a package of rooster saddle feathers that would have cost around $60 at a fly shop now priced from $200 to $400.
A package of the most popular fly tying hackle for hair extensions, a black and white striped feather called grizzly saddle, would normally retail anywhere from $40 to $60. It sold for $480 on eBay last month after 31 bids.
At the Boise salon, Ambroz has stowed away enough feathers to last about six months.
On a recent Tuesday evening, Emilee Rivers, 16, sifted through a pile of rooster saddle feathers looking for the perfect strands to frame her face. She picked out four and handed them to the stylist, who bonded them together with hot glue before clipping them into Rivers' blond hair.
Brandi Wheeler, 16, was next. There's only one other girl at Borah High School in Boise who has the feather extensions, the teenagers said.
Now, they were joining the select few.
"I've wanted to get them for quite a while," Rivers said.
She went to the salon with her mom, Kristi, who totally gets it.
"My dad on the other hand, he's so confused," Rivers said. "I told him what I was doing and he said: 'Why would you get feathers in your hair?'"
ID_Code: DS-106060305

Half-Gallon Challenge not for half-pints

Información de publicación: Times Record News ; Wichita Falls, Tex. [Wichita Falls, Tex]. 05 June 2011: C.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/half-gallon-challenge-not-pints/docview/2610880943/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Half-Gallon+Challenge+not+for+half-pints%3A+Hikers+stop+for+ice+cream+on+2K-mile+trail&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.2&amp;date=2011-06-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Times+Record+News&amp;issn=0895-6138&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: GARDNERS, Pa. Appalachian Trail through-hiker Alan Downs figured it would be a breeze to down a half-gallon of chocolate ice cream. He plunked his money at the Pine Grove Furnace Store, took his carton to a nearby lake and tucked in. If I can make it through this, I can make it to Maine, he told himself.
With that, Downs began the Half-Gallon Challenge.
For the past three decades, long-distance hikers arriving at the midway point of the 2,180-mile Georgia-to-Maine footpath have made it a tradition to stop at Pine Grove Furnace State Park in south-central Pennsylvania and eat an entire brick of ice cream.
The reward: bragging rights, a small commemorative wooden spoon stamped in red letters with Member of Half Gal. Club, and, quite likely, an upset stomach or a nasty case of brain freeze.
About 350 through-hikers each year successfully complete the gastronomic feat, according to Don Ray, who managed the park store for a decade. But it's not easy, even for trail-hardened hikers who can burn 4,000 to 6,000 calories a day and still lose weight while consuming vast quantities of food.
Nearly every through-hiker has heard of the challenge. Many take it seriously, racing one another and timing themselves with stopwatches. Appalachian Trail lore says that if you finish your carton, you get it for free, but that's incorrect: Everyone pays $5.95.
CREDIT:

Materia: Hiking; Ice cream; Parks & recreation areas

Lugar: United States--US Maine

Empresa/organización: Nombre: Appalachian Trail; NAICS: 712190

at Seattle 140-130 Tampa Bay

____________________________________________________________

Half-Gallon Challenge not for half-pints

Autor: Rubinkam, Michael.

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 05 June 2011: A.2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/half-gallon-challenge-not-pints/docview/2569078923/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Half-Gallon+Challenge+not+for+half-pints%3A+Hikers+stop+for+ice+cream+on+2K-mile+trail&amp;author=Rubinkam%2C+Michael&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.2&amp;date=2011-06-05&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: GARDNERS, Pa. Appalachian Trail through-hiker Alan Downs figured it would be a breeze to down a half-gallon of chocolate ice cream. He plunked his money at the Pine Grove Furnace Store, took his carton to a nearby lake and tucked in. If I can make it through this, I can make it to Maine, he told himself.
With that, Downs began the Half-Gallon Challenge.
For the past three decades, long-distance hikers arriving at the midway point of the 2,180-mile Georgia-to-Maine footpath have made it a tradition to stop at Pine Grove Furnace State Park in south-central Pennsylvania and eat an entire brick of ice cream.
The reward: bragging rights, a small commemorative wooden spoon stamped in red letters with Member of Half Gal. Club, and, quite likely, an upset stomach or a nasty case of brain freeze.
About 350 through-hikers each year successfully complete the gastronomic feat, according to Don Ray, who managed the park store for a decade. But it's not easy, even for trail-hardened hikers who can burn 4,000 to 6,000 calories a day and still lose weight while consuming vast quantities of food.
Nearly every through-hiker has heard of the challenge. Many take it seriously, racing one another and timing themselves with stopwatches. Appalachian Trail lore says that if you finish your carton, you get it for free, but that's incorrect: Everyone pays $5.95.

Materia: Hiking; Ice cream; Parks & recreation areas

Lugar: United States--US Maine

Empresa/organización: Nombre: Appalachian Trail; NAICS: 712190

Título: Half-Gallon Challenge not for half-pints:   Hikers stop for ice cream on 2K-mile trail

Autor: Rubinkam, Michael

Título de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times; Corpus Christi

Primera página: A.2

Año de publicación: 2011

Fecha de publicación: Jun 5, 2011

Sección: Wire

Editorial: Gannett Media Corp

Lugar de publicación: Corpus Christi

País de publicación: United States, Corpus Christi

Materia de publicación: General Interest Periodicals--United States

____________________________________________________________

Colts Neck H.S. grad, 23, charged with manslaughter

Autor: Alesha Williams Boyd.

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 04 June 2011: 2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/colts-neck-h-s-grad-23-charged-with-manslaughter/docview/1317094158/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Holland's death was ruled a homicide, according to Brandy DesRosier, a spokeswoman for the Maine Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Colts+Neck+H.S.+grad%2C+23%2C+charged+with+manslaughter&amp;author=Alesha+Williams+Boyd&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=2&amp;date=2011-06-04&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo:   COLTS NECK A 23-year-old Colts Neck man has been charged with manslaughter in the Farmington, Maine shooting of his 23-year-old co-worker.
Ryan Ouimet, 23, of Colts Neck, was with Andrew Holland, 23, of Cape Elizabeth, Maine and Caroline Halloran, 23, of Acton, Mass., in Halloran's Farmington apartment when a handgun went off at about 10:30 p.m. Tuesday. Holland was shot in the abdomen. He was transported by ambulance to Franklin Memorial Hospital in Farmington, where he died, according to Maine Department of Public Safety spokesman Steve McCausland.
The shooting "may not have been intentional but there's concern that with a loaded firearm going off inside an apartment and killing someone that proper firearm procedures were not followed," McCausland said.
Holland's death was ruled a homicide, according to Brandy DesRosier, a spokeswoman for the Maine Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.
Ouimet had recently purchased the gun and was legally permitted to have it, McCausland said. McCausland declined to say whether drug or alcohol use had been involved.
All three were graduates of the University of Maine at Farmington, McCausland said. Ouimet had just graduated in May with a bachelor's of fine arts degree in creative writing, according to the university. He is a graduate of Colts Neck High School.
The three also were working together for the summer at the Olde Post Office Cafe in nearby Mt. Vernon, Maine, according to the Maine Department of Public Safety.
.
Ouimet was released from Franklin County Jail on $10,000 bail. He is expected to appear June 8 in Franklin County Superior Court in Farmington.

Materia: Firearms; Awards & honors; Owner operator; Manslaughter

Lugar: Netherlands Maine

Empresa/organización: Nombre: University of Maine; NAICS: 611310

Today in History

Información de publicación: Asbury Park Press ; Asbury Park, N.J. [Asbury Park, N.J]. 02 June 2011: 2.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/today-history/docview/1317099091/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: President Grover Cleveland, 49, married Frances Folsom, who at 21 became America's youngest first lady, in the Blue Room of the White House.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Today+in+History&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=2&amp;date=2011-06-02&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asbury+Park+Press&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo:   Today in History
Today is Thursday, June 2, the 153rd day of 2011. There are 212 days left in the year.
1851: Maine became the first state to enact a total ban on the manufacture and sale of liquor.
1855: Rioting broke out in Portland, Maine, over rumors a stash of liquor (which would have been legal for "medicinal and mechanical purposes" under the Maine Law) was being kept inside City Hall.
1886: President Grover Cleveland, 49, married Frances Folsom, who at 21 became America's youngest first lady, in the Blue Room of the White House. (To date, Cleveland is the only president to marry in the executive mansion.)
1897: Mark Twain, 61, was quoted by the New York Journal as saying from London that "the report of my death was an exaggeration."

Astros break losing streak

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 31 May 2011: C.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/astros-break-losing-streak/docview/2568350996/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Astros+break+losing+streak&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=C.3&amp;date=2011-05-31&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: CHICAGO Clint Barmes knew his team needed a lift.
He gave them a spark.
Barmes hit the first of four Houston home runs and the Astros rallied to beat the Chicago Cubs 12-7 on Monday.
Barmes' fifth-inning two-run shot brought Houston within one run, then Hunter Pence followed with a game-tying solo homer as the Astros halted a three-game losing streak.
We're just staying positive and making things happen, Barmes said.
J.R. Towles gave the Astros the lead with a leadoff home run in the sixth inning off Cubs reliever Jeff Samardzija (3-1). Jeff Keppinger added a three-run shot in the ninth inning to put things out of reach. He finished with three hits and four RBIs.
The Astros reached season-highs in runs and home runs, matching their best output this year with 16 hits. They scored 11 runs on 16 hits April 12 against the Cubs in an 11-2 victory in Houston.

____________________________________________________________

Daughter charged in boy's death 'needs help'

Información de publicación: Times Record News ; Wichita Falls, Tex. [Wichita Falls, Tex]. 29 May 2011: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/daughter-charged-boys-death-needs-help/docview/2609947369/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Daughter+charged+in+boy%27s+death+%27needs+help%27&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2011-05-29&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Times+Record+News&amp;issn=0895-6138&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: GRAND PRAIRIE A woman charged with killing her 6-year-old son did not do it out of malice, but something snapped, and she needs help, the boy's grandmother told mourners at his funeral Saturday.
As more than 100 people gathered to remember Camden Pierce Hughes, the curly haired, blue-eyed boy who loved reading and playing the guitar, his grandmother said the family's world fell apart when he was found dead under his favorite blanket along a dirt road in Maine two weeks ago.
But she cautioned against judging her jailed daughter, Julianne McCrery.
How do we forgive ... (her) for committing this unspeakable act? I don't know, LuRae McCrery of Curtis, Neb., said during the hourlong service at Calvary Baptist Church in Grand Prairie. I know in my heart that Juli didn't do this out of malice or anger. She was a good mother.
Julianne McCrery, 42, of the Dallas suburb of Irving, is being held without bail on second-degree murder charges in New Hampshire. She is accused of killing her son in Hampton, N.H., on May 14 and dumping his body in South Berwick, Maine. Preliminary autopsy findings show he died of asphyxiation.
A lawyer who represented her at a brief hearing in Massachusetts, where she was detained following a police tip a few days after Camden's body was found, said he thinks she may have traveled hundreds of miles from home with the idea of taking her son's life and committing suicide.
CREDIT:

____________________________________________________________

Daughter charged in boy's death needs help

Información de publicación: Standard Times ; San Angelo [San Angelo]. 29 May 2011: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/daughter-charged-boys-death-needs-help/docview/2593778973/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Daughter+charged+in+boy%27s+death+needs+help%3A+Grandmother+says+child%27s+mom+snapped&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2011-05-29&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Standard+Times&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: GRAND PRAIRIE A woman charged with killing her 6-year-old son did not do it out of malice, but something snapped, and she needs help, the boy's grandmother told mourners at his funeral Saturday.
As more than 100 people gathered to remember Camden Pierce Hughes, the curly haired, blue-eyed boy who loved reading and playing the guitar, his grandmother said the family's world fell apart when he was found dead under his favorite blanket along a dirt road in Maine two weeks ago.
But she cautioned against judging her jailed daughter, Julianne McCrery, and said the family was suffering a double loss.
How do we forgive ... (her) for committing this unspeakable act? I don't know, LuRae McCrery of Curtis, Neb., said during the hourlong service at Calvary Baptist Church in Grand Prairie. I know in my heart that Juli didn't do this out of malice or anger. She was a good mother. ... She did the best she could with what she had. On that fateful day something snapped, and I pray that she gets all the help she needs.
Julianne McCrery, 42, of the Dallas suburb of Irving, is being held without bail on second-degree murder charges in New Hampshire. She is accused of killing her son in Hampton, N.H., on May 14 and dumping his body near the state line about 20 miles away in South Berwick, Maine. Preliminary autopsy findings show he died of asphyxiation.
A lawyer who represented her at a brief hearing in Massachusetts, where she was detained following a police tip a few days after Camden's body was found, said he thinks she may have traveled hundreds of miles from home with the idea of taking her son's life and committing suicide.
CREDIT:

Preliminary autopsy findings show he died of asphyxiation.
A lawyer who represented her at a brief hearing in Massachusetts, where she was detained following a police tip a few days after Camden's body was found, said he thinks she may have traveled hundreds of miles from home with the idea of taking her son's life and committing suicide.

____________________________________________________________

Obituaries

Información de publicación: The Stuart News ; Stuart, Fla. [Stuart, Fla]. 27 May 2011: A.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/obituaries/docview/2608867538/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Obituaries&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;date=2011-05-27&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Stuart+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Sara Svelling
Sebastian
Sara O'Connel Svelling, 74, died May 20, 2011, at VNA Hospice House in Vero Beach.
She was born in Bangor, Maine, and lived in Sebastian for 37 years, coming from Manahawkin, N.J.
She was a homemaker.
Survivors include her husband of 55 years, Arnold; sons, Kris Svelling of Sebastian and Arnold Svelling Jr. Of Charleston, S.C.; daughters, Esther Svelling Cummins of Sebastian and Kristine Lanera of White Plains, N.Y.; 13 grandchildren; and eight great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her brother, Jeff O'Connel.
Memorial contributions may be made to the VNA Hospice House, 1111 36th St. Vero Beach. FL 32960.
Barbara Kelly
Sebastian
Barbara Jean Bobbie Kelly, 70, died May 17, 2011, at Sebastian River Medical Center, Roseland.
She was born in Hampton, Va., and lived in Sebastian for 39 years.
Before retirement, she was a bartender.
She was a member of Eagles Aerie 4067 in Sebastian and Orioles 272 in Micco and a life member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars Auxiliary of Sebastian.
Survivors include her husband of 20 years, Richard Rich Kelly of Sebastian; daughter, Kristina Davis of Sebastian; and a grandchild.
Pearl Cole
Sebastian
Pearl Lee Cole, 89, died May 13, 2011.
She was born in Estill County, Ky., and lived in Sebastian since 1982, coming from Fairfield, Ohio.
Before becoming a homemaker, she worked as a government employee at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base during and after World War II.
She was a volunteer for the Congregate Meals at the Sebastian Community Center.
She graduated from Stewart High School, Oxford, Ohio.
Survivors include her son, Thomas L. Cole of Fort Pierce; and two grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her husband in 2008, Orville; and brothers, Henry Stevens, Leon Stevens and Edward Stevens.
Memorial contributions may be made to the VNA Hospice House, 901 37th St., Vero Beach, FL 32960.
Jacob Pierce
Barefoot Bay
Jacob Matthew Pierce, 19, died May 16, 2011, in Micco.
He was born in Melbourne and lived in Barefoot Bay.
He was employed as a busboy for the Eagles Nest restaurant, Sebastian.
He attended St. Sebastian Catholic Church, Sebastian.
Survivors include his daughter, Elizabeth Rose Pierce of Palm Bay; parents, Saundra and Esau Gutierrez of Barefoot Bay; sisters, Brianna Gutierrez of Barefoot Bay and Felicia Pierce of Louisville, Ky.; grandfather, Charles Pierce of Louisville; and grandmother, Margarita Hernandez of Vera Cruz, Mexico.
Iris Beaupre
Micco
Iris Margaret Beaupre, 88, died May 20, 2011, at Sebastian River Medical Center, Sebastian.
She was born in Dexter, Maine, and lived in Micco for nine years, coming from Port St. Lucie.
She was the owner of her own beautician business.
Survivors include her daughter, Mary B. Tucker of Palm Bay; sister, Marise Hartley of DeBary; and one grandchild.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Albert Bert Beaupre; daughter, Joy Beaupre Hudek; sister, Alma Lessard; and brother, Chib Clukey.
Memorial contributions may be made to VNA & Hospice Foundation, 1111 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960.
Pasquale Lonardo
Sebastian
Pasquale Lonardo, 76, died May 20, 2011, at the Sebastian River Medical Center.
He was born in Providence, R.I., and lived in Sebastian for 17 years, coming from Clearwater.
He was a self-employed painter.
He was a member of St. Sebastian Catholic Church.
Survivors include his wife of 24 years, Elizabeth Lonardo of Sebastian; daughters, Linda Monterio of Westerly, R.I., Terri Mottola of Cranston, R.I., Debbie Lonardo of N.J., and Lori Linardo of Cranston, R.I.; sons, Steven Monterio of Miami and Bill Palazzi of Sebastian; sisters, Quilda, Camille and Paula; and two grandchildren.
He is preceded in death by his sons, Pasquale Jr. and William Lonardo.

____________________________________________________________

Get in line now for summer theater tickets

Autor: Keyes, Bob.

Información de publicación: Portland Press Herald ; Portland, Me. [Portland, Me]. 26 May 2011: E.25.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/get-line-now-summer-theater-tickets/docview/868666339/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Special events include a concert version of the Tony Award-winning musical "Spring Awakening," the folk duo Schooner Fare and the return of Tony nominee Euan Morton. The season is currently under way with "I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change" through June 4, followed by "Up the Down Staircase" (June 9-18), "Heaven Help Me" (June 23-July 2), "Sugar" (July 7-16), "Moon Over Buffalo" (July 21-30), "Once Upon a Mattress" (Aug. 4-13), "The Red Velvet Cake War" (Aug. 18-27), "To Kill a Mockingbird" (Sept. 1-10) and "Wrong Window" (Sept. 15-24).

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Get+in+line+now+for+summer+theater+tickets%3A+Summer+in+Maine+seems+to+vanish+as+soon+as+it+arrives.+So+do+tickets+for+the+best+shows.&amp;author=Keyes%2C+Bob&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=E.25&amp;date=2011-05-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Portland+Press+Herald&amp;issn=2689-5900&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: The thing about summer in Maine is that when it finally arrives, it seems to vanish in no time at all. Summer theater is something like that, too.
If you want to attend a show, don't dawdle. Time moves fast, and oftentimes so do tickets. Here are some of the highlights of the season ahead:
* MAINE STATE MUSIC THEATRE, Brunswick: Maine State's 53rd season includes four mainstage musicals, three concerts and two children's musicals.
The mainstage opens with "The Marvelous Wonderettes" (June 8-25), which finds four high school seniors - Betty Jean, Cindy Lou, Missy and Suzy - prepping for their 1958 high school prom. They reveal their lives and loves through popular hit songs of the 1950s. After intermission, they travel forward to their 10-year reunion, and reminisce through songs of the 1960s.
The show stars Brittney Morello, Lara Seibert, Danielle Erin Rhodes and Morgan Smith. Morello stepped in last summer at Maine State to play the lead in "My Fair Lady" when the original cast member lost her voice. She has performed at North Shore Music Theatre and Speakeasy Stage Company in Massachusetts, and with Summer Theatre Meredith Village in New Hampshire.
Seibert starred as the bride-to-be in 2009's "The Drowsy Chaperone" at Maine State. Her Broadway credits include "Young Frankenstein," and she was part of the national tour of "The Producers."
Rhodes has toured in productions of "Grease" and "Oliver!" Smith has performed Off-Broadway and with multiple acclaimed regional theaters.
The rest of the mainstage season includes "Annie," June 29-July 16; "Xanadu," July 20-Aug. 6; and "The Wiz," Aug. 10-27. Special events include a concert version of the Tony Award-winning musical "Spring Awakening," the folk duo Schooner Fare and the return of Tony nominee Euan Morton.
The children's programming includes a musical version of the popular book "Click, Clack, Moo" and a new interpretation of "Beauty and the Beast."
The company performs at Pickard Theater at Bowdoin College. For times, tickets and other details, visit msmt.org or call 725-8769.
* LAKEWOOD THEATER, Madison: The season is currently under way with "I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change" through June 4, followed by "Up the Down Staircase" (June 9-18), "Heaven Help Me" (June 23-July 2), "Sugar" (July 7-16), "Moon Over Buffalo" (July 21-30), "Once Upon a Mattress" (Aug. 4-13), "The Red Velvet Cake War" (Aug. 18-27), "To Kill a Mockingbird" (Sept. 1-10) and "Wrong Window" (Sept. 15-24). Call 474-7176 or visit lakewoodtheater.org.
* DRAMATIC REPERTORY COMPANY, Portland: The non-profit company concludes its inaugural, two-show season with "Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde" (June 2-12) at Portland Stage's Studio Theater. Call (800) 838-3006 or visit dramaticrep.org.
* ARUNDEL BARN PLAYHOUSE, Arundel: The season begins June 7 with "The 39 Steps," through June 25, followed by "Crazy for You" (June 28-July 16), "The Wizard of Oz" (July 19-Aug. 6), "A Taffeta Wedding" (Aug. 9-20) and "I Left My Heart: A Salute to the Music of Tony Bennett" (Aug. 23-Sept. 3). Call 985-5552 or visit arundelbarnplayhouse.com.
* ACORN PRODUCTIONS: The Westbrook-based Acorn will present a unique version of Shakespeare's "Cymbeline" at 2 p.m. June 25-26. The company will present what it is calling "Cymbeline Underground" at Battery Steel on Peaks Island. Call 854-0065 or visit acorn-productions.org.
* HACKMATACK PLAYHOUSE, Berwick: The season begins with "Ten Nights in a Barroom" (June 29-July 2) and continues with "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" (July 6-23), "Singin' in the Rain" (July 27-Aug. 13) and "The 39 Steps" (Aug. 17-Sept. 3). Call 698-1807 or visit hackmatack.org.
* OPERA HOUSE ARTS at Stonington Opera House: Enjoy Shakespeare in Stonington with "Much Ado About Nothing" and "Elizabeth Rex" June 30 through July 17. Call 367-2788 or visit operahousearts.org.
* ACADIA REPERTORY THEATRE, Mount Desert: The season opens with "The Mystery of Irma Vep" (July 1-17) and continues with "44 Plays for 44 Residents" (July 19-31), "Blithe Spirit" (Aug. 2-14) and "Sherlock Holmes and the Case of the Jersey Lily" (Aug. 16-Sept. 4). Call 244-7260 or visit acadiarep.com.
* HEARTWOOD REGIONAL THEATER
COMPANY, Damariscotta: Heartwood will present "Sunday in the Park with George" July 1-2, 8-9 and 15-17. Call 563-1373 or visit heartwoodtheater.org.
* THEATER AT MONMOUTH, Monmouth: The Shakespearean theater of Maine presents its shows in repertory, so the schedule moves and shifts around. This summer's productions include "Much Ado About Nothing" (July 7-Aug. 20), "Room Service" (July 14-Aug. 20), "The Compleat Works of William Shakespeare, abridged" (July 10 and 20, and Aug. 2 and 17), "Black Fly Follies," an annual variety show (July 2), "Blithe Spirit" (July 22-Aug. 19), "King Lear" (July 29-Aug. 18), "James and the Giant Peach" (Aug. 2-19) and "On the Twentieth Century" (Sept. 23-Oct. 2). Call 933-9999 or visit theateratmonmouth.org.
* FENIX THEATRE CO., Portland: Fenix performs free shows at Deering Oaks park. This summer's lineup, in repertory, includes two shows: Samuel Beckett's "Waiting for Godot" on July 15, 21, 23 and 29, and Aug. 4, 6 and 12; and Shakespeare's "Loves Labors Lost" on July 14, 16, 22 and 28, and Aug. 5, 11 and 13. Call 400-6223 or visit fenixtheatre.com.
* NORTHPORT MUSIC THEATER, Northport: "The Bikinis" will be presented July 22-31. Call 338-8383 or visit northportmusictheater.com.
* CITY THEATER, Biddeford: The City Theater will present "Gypsy" July 22 to Aug. 6. Call 282-0849 or visit citytheater.org.
* FREEPORT SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL, Freeport: The mainstage production of "Twelfth Night" opens at the L.L. Bean Discovery Park Stage Aug. 2 and runs through Aug. 12. All performances are free. The festival will host "Before Bill," a comic romp through medieval times, at the Freeport Factory Stage, 5 Depot St., July 28 to Aug. 14. Call 865-9299 or visit freeportshakespeare festival. org.
* DEERTREES THEATRE FESTIVAL, Harrison: This year's festival has four shows, including three musicals: "The Bikinis" (Aug. 3-7), "Burt & Me" (Aug. 10-14) and "Monsters! The Musical" (Aug. 17-21). The drama "Breakfast with Mary" (Aug. 24-28) will close the season. Call 538-6747 or visit deertreestheatre.org.
Credit: By BOB KEYES Staff Writer
Illustration Caption: From left, Danielle Erin Rhodes, Brittney Morello, Morgan Smith and Lara Seibert star in Maine State Music Theatre's "The Marvelous Wonderettes," running June 8-25.

Materia: Community theater

Lugar: Maine

Título: Get in line now for summer theater tickets:   Summer in Maine seems to vanish as soon as it arrives. So do tickets for the best shows.

Autor: Keyes, Bob

____________________________________________________________

Memorial service planned for Harte

Autor: Meyers, Rhiannon.

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 26 May 2011: B.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/memorial-service-planned-harte/docview/2571220926/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Memorial+service+planned+for+Harte&amp;author=Meyers%2C+Rhiannon&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;date=2011-05-26&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: A memorial service for philanthropist and former Caller-Times Publisher Edward H. Harte is scheduled for mid-June in Corpus Christi.
Harte died May 18in Maine at age 88, leaving a legacy of environmental preservation, generous giving and the $46 million endowment of the Harte Research Institute, now a leader in Gulf of Mexico studies.
A ceremony remembering Harte will be held at 4:30 p.m. June 14 at Parkway Presbyterian, 3707 Santa Fe St.
Dad always considered Corpus Christi his home even when he spent time in New York and Maine, said his son Chris Harte. This was always Mother's and Dad's home, from 1956 until the end.
Harte and his wife donated at least $70 million locally to causes including higher education, environmental research and conservation, but the extent of their philanthropy remains unknown because they gave anonymously for years.
Harte was intensely interested in environmental conservation, lobbying the government to create Mustang Island State Park and Padre Island National Seashore to better protect the fragile coastal habitats and wildlife. He and his brother also donated their 66,000-acre ranch to Big Bend National Park.
Harte, whose father co-founded the Harte-Hanks newspaper company, served as publisher of the Caller-Times for 25 years, where he was most famously known for his longtime Sunday column that provided an insight into Mexican politics and current events not available in the mainstream press. He continued the column even after his retirement in 1987.
Corpus Christi was the most important paper to Harte-Hanks' success and Dad always appreciated that, and that's why his largest gift was to establish the Harte Research Institute in Corpus Christi, Chris Harte said.
Harte is preceded in death by his wife, Janet, who died in 1999.
His ashes will be buried alongside Janet's in Thetford, Vt., in a private family ceremony this summer.

Materia: Parks & recreation areas; Memorial services; National parks

Wanted man calls cops by accident

Información de publicación: Times Record News ; Wichita Falls, Tex. [Wichita Falls, Tex]. 25 May 2011: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/wanted-man-calls-cops-accident/docview/2609907563/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Wanted+man+calls+cops+by+accident&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2011-05-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Times+Record+News&amp;issn=0895-6138&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: BANGOR, Maine Police in Maine say a man wanted for failing to pay fines accidentally helped officers find him when he repeatedly pocket dialed 911 while doing yard work.
Police say 29-year-old James Green was using a backpack leaf blower in Bangor Saturday when he kept calling 911 without realizing it.
Police Lt. Jeff Millard says officers were able to determine where the calls were coming from by triangulating the signal from Green's phone.
The Bangor Daily News says there were two active warrants for Green's arrest for failure to pay fines.

Boy's body back in Texas

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 25 May 2011: B.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/boys-body-back-texas/docview/2570567699/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Boy%27s+body+back+in+Texas&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.3&amp;date=2011-05-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: AUGUSTA, Maine A family friend says the body of a boy left along a dirt road in Maine is back in Texas for a funeral to be held this weekend.
Shirley Miller, a longtime friend in Texas, told The Associated Press Tuesday that the body of 6-year-old Camden Hughes is back on Texas soil. The funeral is scheduled for Saturday.
Camden's body was released Friday by the Maine medical examiner.
The boy's mother, Julianne McCrery of Irving, is being held in New Hampshire, where she's charged with killing the boy before leaving him in South Berwick, Maine.
Miller says McCrery's father, her other son and the son's father traveled to Maine to retrieve Camden's remains.

Lugar: Texas United States--US Maine

____________________________________________________________

Edward H. Harte to be memorialized in June in Corpus Christi

Autor: Meyers, Rhiannon.

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 25 May 2011.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/edward-h-harte-be-memorialized-june-corpus/docview/1530421759/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Harte, whose father cofounded the Harte-Hanks newspaper company, served as publisher of the Caller-Times for 25 years, where he was most famously known for his longtime Sunday column that provided an insight into Mexican politics and current events not available in the mainstream press.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Edward+H.+Harte+to+be+memorialized+in+June+in+Corpus+Christi&amp;author=Meyers%2C+Rhiannon&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2011-05-25&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo:   CORPUS CHRISTI -- A memorial service for philanthropist and former Caller-Times Publisher Edward H. Harte is scheduled for mid-June in Corpus Christi.
Harte died May 18 in Maine at the age of 88, leaving a legacy of environmental preservation, generous giving and the $46 million endowment of the Harte Research Institute, now a leader in Gulf of Mexico studies.
A ceremony remembering Harte will be held at 4:30 p.m. June 14 at Parkway Presbyterian, 3707 Santa Fe St.
"Dad always considered Corpus Christi his home even when he spent time in New York and Maine," his son, Chris Harte, said. "This was always Mother's and Dad's home, from 1956 until the end."
Harte and his wife donated at least $70 million locally to causes including higher education, environmental research and conservation, but the extent of their philanthropy remains unknown because they gave anonymously for years.
Harte was intensely interested in environmental conservation, lobbying government to create Mustang Island State Park and Padre Island National Seashore to better protect the fragile coastal habitats and wildlife. He and his brother also donated their 66,000-acre ranch to Big Bend National Park.
Harte, whose father cofounded the Harte-Hanks newspaper company, served as publisher of the Caller-Times for 25 years, where he was most famously known for his longtime Sunday column that provided an insight into Mexican politics and current events not available in the mainstream press. He continued the column even after his retirement in 1987.
"Corpus Christi was the most important paper to Harte-Hanks' success and Dad always appreciated that, and that's why his largest gift was to establish the Harte Research Institute in Corpus Christi," Chris Harte said.
Harte is preceded in death by his wife, Janet, who died in 1999.
His ashes will be buried alongside Janet's in Thetford, Vt., in a private family ceremony this summer.

Materia: Environmental protection; Newspapers; Parks & recreation areas

Lugar: Maine

Título: Edward H. Harte to be memorialized in June in Corpus Christi

Autor: Meyers, Rhiannon

Título de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times; Corpus Christi

Boy's kin thankful for kind gestures Slain child's mother accused of killing him

Información de publicación: Times Record News ; Wichita Falls, Tex. [Wichita Falls, Tex]. 21 May 2011: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/boys-kin-thankful-kind-gestures-slain-childs/docview/2610049991/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Boy%27s+kin+thankful+for+kind+gestures+Slain+child%27s+mother+accused+of+killing+him&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2011-05-21&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Times+Record+News&amp;issn=0895-6138&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: CONCORD, N.H. The grandmother of the 6-year-old boy found dead along a dirt road in Maine said she's heartbroken over what happened to the bright child who liked to practice writing his letters and kick a football and soccer ball in the backyard.
Camden and I share the same birthday on March 15th, and my birthday will never be the same again, LuRae McCrery of Curtis, Neb., said in an open letter to news media. It seems like a very bad nightmare from which I will never wake up.
McCrery's daughter, Julianne McCrery, was ordered held without bail Thursday on second-degree murder charges in New Hampshire. She's accused of killing her son, 6-year-old Camden Hughes, in Hampton, N.H., on Saturday, and dumping his body in South Berwick, Maine. Preliminary autopsy findings showed he died of asphyxiation.
Julianne McCrery, 42, of Irving, Texas, was detained Wednesday at a highway rest stop in Chelmsford, Mass., after police got a tip about her pickup truck, which matched a vehicle seen near the spot where the boy's body was found. Friends have described her as a loving mother who was prone to mood swings; a lawyer who represented her at a brief hearing in Massachusetts said based on his conversations with her, he thinks she may have traveled hundreds of miles from home with the idea of taking her son's life and committing suicide.
School officials in Texas said the boy last attended kindergarten on May 6, and that his mother continued to call this week to report that he was ill. Meanwhile, the case was drawing national attention as the boy went unidentified for days.
Residents of South Berwick held a candlelight vigil in his honor.
It was very special of your city to remember someone that nobody ever knew, LuRae McCrery wrote in her letter. There are so many family and friends that are profoundly affected by this senseless loss of a little boy.
CREDIT:

Boy's kin thankful for kind gestures Slain child's mother accused of killing him

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 21 May 2011: A.6.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/boys-kin-thankful-kind-gestures-slain-childs/docview/2569491235/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Boy%27s+kin+thankful+for+kind+gestures+Slain+child%27s+mother+accused+of+killing+him&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;date=2011-05-21&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: CONCORD, N.H. The grandmother of the 6-year-old boy found dead along a dirt road in Maine says she's heartbroken over what happened to the bright child who liked to practice writing his letters and kick a football and soccer ball in the backyard.
Camden and I share the same birthday on March 15, and my birthday will never be the same again, LuRae McCrery of Curtis, Neb., said in an open letter to news media. It seems like a very bad nightmare from which I will never wake up.
McCrery's daughter, Julianne McCrery, was ordered held without bail Thursday on second-degree murder charges in New Hampshire. She's accused of killing her son, 6-year-old Camden Hughes, in Hampton, N.H., on Saturday, and dumping his body in South Berwick, Maine. Preliminary autopsy findings showed he died of asphyxiation.
Julianne McCrery, 42, of Irving, Texas, was detained Wednesday at a highway rest stop in Chelmsford, Mass., after police got a tip about her pickup truck, which matched a vehicle seen near the spot where the boy's body was found. Friends have described her as a loving mother who was prone to mood swings; a lawyer who represented her at a brief hearing in Massachusetts said based on his conversations with her, he thinks she may have traveled hundreds of miles from home with the idea of taking her son's life and committing suicide.
Residents of South Berwick held a candlelight vigil in his honor.
It was very special of your city to remember someone that nobody ever knew, LuRae McCrery wrote in her letter. There are so many family and friends that are profoundly affected by this senseless loss of a little boy.
