Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Obituaries&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.4&amp;date=2011-04-18&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Stuart+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: Lily Bell Carter
Fort Pierce
Lily Bell Carter, 78, died April 16, 2011, in Fort Pierce.
She was born in Cornwell and moved to Fort Pierce in 1954, coming from Okeechobee.
She was a homemaker.
Survivors include her daughters, Linda Robinson and Debbie Carter, both of Fort Pierce, and Tricia Lamb of Cullman, Ala.; sons, Herbert Carter of Sardis, Tenn. and Malcolm Carter of Cullman; sister, Dorothy Douglas of Okeechobee; brothers, Billy Johnson of Sardis, Tenn., Jake Johnson of Okeechobee, and Phillip Johnson of Fort Pierce; eight grandchildren and 15 great grandchildren.
Services: Visitation will be from 10 to 11 a.m. April 19, with a service to follow at 11 a.m. at Haisley Funeral Home. Burial will follow at White City Cemetery. A guestbook may be signed at haisleyfuneralhome.com.
Helen H. Decker
Port St. Lucie
Helen H. Decker, 94, died April 13, 2011, at Treasure Coast Hospice in Fort Pierce.
She was born in Hanover, Pa., and had been a resident of Port St. Lucie for 32 years, coming from Silver Springs, Md.
She retired from the Department of Defense in White Oaks, Md., where she worked for 19 years until 1972.
She was a member of the First Congregational Church of Port St. Lucie, Riverfront Bridge Club of Port St. Lucie, and was a volunteer at the St. Lucie Medical Center.
Survivors include a daughter, Jeanne Hoffman of Port St. Lucie; son, Jack M. Decker of Bowie, Md.; and one grandchild.
She was preceded in death by her husband, Ralph M. Decker; sisters, Viola Abbott and Harriett Reck; and brother, Robert Hetrick.
Memorial contributions may be made to Treasure Coast Hospices, 5090 Dunn Road, Fort Pierce, FL. 34981; 772-403-4500; or tchospice.org.
Services: A memorial service will be at 11 a.m. April 21 the First Congregational Church of Port St. Lucie, 2401 S.E. Sidonia St. Arrangements are by All County Funeral Home & Crematory, Treasure Coast Chapel.
Judith Gills
Hobe Sound
Judith Eger Gills, 66, died April 16, 2011, at the Treasure Coast Hospice Harper House, Stuart.
She was born in Tampa, and had lived in Hobe Sound for 15 years.
Before retiring she was a registered nurse, practicing in trauma and intensive care units, private duty nursing and home health care. She also worked with homeless people.
She was a member of the First Baptist Church of Hobe Sound, where she was the head of the prayer chain.
Survivors include her husband, William Kennard Gills of Hobe Sound; sons, Jonathan Kennard Gills of Delray Beach and Matthew L. Gills of Hobe Sound; sister, Kaye Eger Stotler of Paradise, Calif.; and two grandchildren.
Memorial contributions may be made to the First Baptist Church of Hobe Sound Building Fund, 8515 S.E. Church St., Hobe Sound, FL 33455-5033; 772-546-5000.

The funeral will be at 1 p.m. April 20 in the funeral home chapel with Pastor Charles Phillips officiating. Interment will follow in Forest Hill Memorial Park, Palm City. A registry is available at youngandprill.com.

Port St. Lucie
Lou M. Henderson, 71, died April 15, 2011, at his home in Port St. Lucie.
He was born in Thomaston, Maine, and moved to Port St. Lucie 10 years ago from Wareham, Mass.
He was a member of the New Bedford Fisherman's Union in New Bedford, Mass.
He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Edna M. Henderson; daughters, Jayne Fontes of New Bedford and Lisa Henderson of Westport, Mass.; son, David Henderson of Italy and Friendship, Maine; three grandchildren and one great-grandchild.
Memorial contributions may be made to Treasure Coast Hospice, 1201 S.E. Indian St., Stuart, FL 34997; 772-403-4500; tchospice.org.
Services: All County Funeral Home & Crematory Treasure Coast Chapel is in charge of arrangements.
Robert Hoctor
Sebastian
Robert F. Hoctor, 83, died April 15, 2011, at the VNA Hospice House.
He was born in Buffalo, N.Y., and lived in Sebastian for nine years, coming from Jonesboro, Tenn.
Before retirement, he was a measurement supervisor for the Tennessee Gas Transmission Co.
He was a member of St. Sebastian Catholic Church, Knights of Columbus and American Legion.
Survivors include his wife of 65 years, Edna Hoctor of Sebastian; daughters; Frances Byrne of Jonesboro, Tenn., and Marilyn Ryan of Burr Ridge, Ill.; sisters, Eileen Hoctor, Florence Rabel and Patricia Herdliein, all of Buffalo; seven grandchildren; and 16 great-grandchildren.
He was preceded in death by his brothers, Kurt Hoctor and Francis Hoctor; and sisters, Audrey Dean and Janet Miller.

Trion, Ga.
Charles Lewis Jewell Jr., 57, died April 13, 2011, at Floyd Medical Center, Rome, Ga.
He was born in Alma, Ga., and lived in Trion, Ga., and was formerly of Fort Pierce.
Prior to retirement, he was self-employed in the flooring industry.
He was a member of the Palm Vista Church of God in Fort Pierce.
He was preceded in death by his father, Charles Lewis Jewell Sr.; mother, Jacqulin Pervis Jewell; wife, Carrie Carver Jewell; granddaughter, Tabatha Shaffer; grandson, Julian Howell; and a close friend, Brother Spooner.

Alice Porcello
Hobe Sound
Alice Porcello, 94, died April 16, 2011, at Martin Memorial Hospital, Stuart.
She was born in Minneapolis, Minn., and had moved to Hobe Sound about a year ago from Westwood, N.J., where she had lived since 1957.
Mrs. Porcello was the deputy registrar for Westwood Board of Health for 32 years, retiring in 2006.
She also was part of a popular 1930s and '40s entertainment troupe known as the Kim Loo Sisters. She traveled the world and performed with entertainers such as Frank Sinatra, Judy Garland and Jackie Gleason. In late 1944, she was sent to Rome on a USO tour of the Mediterranean Theater of Operations.
Survivors include daughter, Jacqulyn Allen; sisters, Margaret Kenyon, Genevieve Jenee Li and Patricia Bubbles Cooper; two grandchildren; eight great-grandchildren; and two great-great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by her husband, John Porcello; daughter, Michele Porcello; sister, Neree Paprota; and brother, Lowell Louie.
Services: Visiting hours are 4 to 8 p.m. Tuesday at the Becker Funeral Home, Westwood, N.J. The funeral will start at 9 a.m. Wednesday at the funeral home, with a funeral Mass to be celebrated at 10 a.m. at St. Andrew's Church, Westwood. Interment will follow in George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, N.J. Local arrangements are by Aycock Funeral Home in Stuart.

Fort Pierce
Donald Vernon Rosendahl, 74, died April 17, 2011, in Fort Pierce.
He was born in Kankakee, Ill., and moved to Fort Pierce in 1986.
He retired from Florida Gas and Transmission. His hobby was classic cars.
He served with the Navy during the Korean War and was a member of American Legion Post 40.
Survivors include his wife of 30 years, Linda Rosendahl of Fort Pierce; daughters, Dawn Rosendahl of Orlando and Denise Walden of Sidney, Ill.; stepson, Richard Burton of Minonk, Ill.; stepdaughter, Kristy Burton of Atlanta, Ill.; sister, Pat Kuhfus of Pheonix; brother, Larry Rosendahl of Pheonix; five grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren.

John V. Scarangella
Port St. Lucie
John V. Scarangella, 68, died April 16, 2011, at Treasure Coast Hospice in Fort Pierce.
He was born in Brooklyn, N.Y. and moved to Port St. Lucie 23 years ago, coming from North Babylon, N.Y.
Before retiring he worked at Grumman Aerospace in Bethpage, N.Y., and Stuart. He also was a driver for United Refrigeration in Port St. Lucie.
He was a member of the Knights of Columbus in New York and was a veteran of the Army.
He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Diane Scarangella of Port St. Lucie; sons, Kenneth Scarangella of Kilgore, Texas and John A. Scarangella of Hermitage, Tenn.; daughter, Sandra Gallway of Port St. Lucie; brother, Frank Scarangella of Levittown, N.Y.; sister, Mary Ann Curry of Levittown, N.Y.; and three grandchildren.
He is preceded in death by his brothers, James and Peter Scarangella.

Lobster shells valuable for golf balls, plant pots

Información de publicación: Kitsap Sun ; Bremerton, Wash. [Bremerton, Wash]. 18 Apr 2011: A.7.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lobster-shells-valuable-golf-balls-plant-pots/docview/2582655785/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Lobster+shells+valuable+for+golf+balls%2C+plant+pots&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.7&amp;date=2011-04-18&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Kitsap+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: ORONO, Maine Lobsters aren't just for eating anymore.
The shells from Maine's signature seafood are being used to manufacture decorative tiles, trivets and drinking-glass coasters. Work is under way to utilize them in countertops and tabletops. And at the University of Maine, a professor has developed prototypes of biodegradable golf balls and plant pots made out of ground-up lobster shells.
Instead of dumping the shells at landfills, the idea is to add value to the product, which hopefully will funnel back into the industry, said David Neivandt, a professor of chemical and biological engineering who created a biodegradable golf ball with a core made of lobster shells.
Lobster processors dispose of tons of lobster shells that are left over after the meat is removed. Industry leaders have long wondered if there might be a way to make money from the part thrown away.
Neivandt and one of his students, Alex Caddell, together developed a golf ball using ground-up lobster shells mixed with a glue-like substance for its core. The shell is also made out of naturally derived biodegradable material, but they aren't giving specifics because they don't want to give away any secrets. The ball is the same size and weight as a standard golf ball but is intended for use on cruise ships or at driving ranges that are on lakes or the ocean.
Dumping golf balls into the sea is prohibited under international convention because they are made of plastic and don't break down, but the lobster golf ball is biodegradable and disintegrates in the water in about three weeks.
Caddell, who played golf in high school, said he and Neivandt tested numerous balls that cracked, didn't fly quite right or otherwise didn't make the cut. Finally, they came upon just the right mixture that makes the ball hit nearly like the real thing.
The first time I hit it, I was surprised it didn't shatter into a million pieces, Caddell said. And it flew straight. I usually have a pretty bad slice, so to hit it straight was amazing.
With an iron, the ball flies nearly the same distance as a standard ball. With a driver, it'll go 60 to 70 percent of the distance.
There are other biodegradable golf balls on the market, which sell for about $1 each, Neivandt said. The raw materials for the lobster golf ball cost about 19 cents per ball, which could make it competitive in the open market.
The university has filed a provisional patent for the lobster-shell mixture. Neivandt said a private company could buy the licensing rights and market the ball, or the school could spin off a company that would produce it.
While developing the golf ball, they also came up with a plant pot made out of lobster shell mixture which has a high calcium content beneficial to flowers and vegetables to place directly in the ground with flowers or vegetable plants.
Turning seafood waste products such as lobster or clam shells into products with commercial value would benefit the seafood industry, said Bob Bayer, head of The Lobster Institute Research and Education organization at the University of Maine.
Most lobster shells are dumped in the garbage or at landfills, Bayer said, with some of it going toward seafood compost used for gardens or turned into lobster meal, which is an animal feed additive. There have been failed efforts to turn the shells into other marketable products such as lobster bait over the years, so Bayer is pleased to see new products come on line.
The whole idea is to add value to our lobster, he said. The more value we can extract, the more fishermen will be paid and more jobs will be created.
CREDIT:

Materia: Seafood; Biodegradable materials; Landfill

Lugar: United States--US Maine

Learning ABCs on iPads

Información de publicación: Kitsap Sun ; Bremerton, Wash. [Bremerton, Wash]. 18 Apr 2011: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/learning-abcs-on-ipads/docview/2582449300/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Learning+ABCs+on+iPads&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2011-04-18&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Kitsap+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: PORTLAND, Maine Kindergarten classes are supplementing crayons, finger paints and flashcards with iPads, a development that excites supporters but that detractors worry is wasted on pupils too young to appreciate the expense.
Next fall, nearly 300 kindergartners in the central Maine city of Auburn will become the latest batch of youngsters around the country to get iPad2 touch pad tablets to learn the basics about ABCs, 1-2-3s, drawing and even music.
It's definitely an adventure, and it'll be a journey of learning for teachers and students, said Auburn kindergarten teacher Amy Heimerl, who received an iPad on Tuesday ahead of the full deployment in the fall. I'm looking forward to seeing where this can take us and our students.
But the $200,000 that Superintendent Tom Morrill is proposing to spend on iPads which retail for around $500 might be better spent on some other school program, said Sue Millard of Auburn, who has children in the fourth grade and high school. She also questions whether kindergartners are old enough to appreciate the effort.
I understand you have to keep up with technology, but I think a 5-year-old is a little too young to understand, she said.
Maine was the first state to equip students statewide with computers when it distributed Apple laptops to all seventh- and eighth-graders in 2002 and 2003. The program since has expanded, with laptops parceled out to about 50 percent of high school students.
The State Department of Education says it believes Auburn is the first school district in Maine that will give iPads to kindergartners. The school board last week unanimously approved the plan to give all kindergartners iPads next fall.
The iPad is a powerful education tool with hundreds of teaching applications, Morrill said. With its touch pad screen, it's simple to use and can bring learning to life with imagery and sounds, he said.
CREDIT:

Materia: Preschool education; Students; Portable computers; Learning

Título: Learning ABCs on iPads

____________________________________________________________

One year after takeover, TD Bank finding its niche

Información de publicación: The Stuart News ; Stuart, Fla. [Stuart, Fla]. 17 Apr 2011: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/one-year-after-takeover-td-bank-finding-niche/docview/2607622495/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=One+year+after+takeover%2C+TD+Bank+finding+its+niche&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2011-04-17&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Stuart+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: FORT PIERCE The Treasure Coast banking world underwent a major change when TD Bank took over for Riverside National Bank a year ago.
To some, the bright green from TD Bank's new marquees represents fresh capital in a Treasure Coast banking sector battered by bad loans, high unemployment and falling home prices.
But for Riverside investors and former employees, the deep blue from the former company's banners represents a long, metaphorical winter for those who lost investments and jobs when Riverside vanished.
The federal government seized Fort Pierce-based Riverside on April 16, 2010 and sold the bank's assets to a subsidiary of Toronto-Dominion Bank, the second largest bank in Canada. Riverside had been St. Lucie County's leader in deposits and reinvested into the area through many sponsorships.
Those with regular checking and savings accounts kept their money and many remained customers. But the exchange eliminated one of the Treasure Coast's largest local banks and turned privately-held Riverside stock once valued at more than $550 per share to dust.
Experts differ on why Riverside failed, but TD bank emerged from the country's banking meltdown not only with dollars to lend, but with money to expand.
The company began serving Florida customers about five years ago with hopes of expanding throughout the state. The availability of Riverside's customer base fell perfectly into TD Bank's plans for getting more Florida locations, said Kevin Gillen, the bank's regional president for Florida.
It was the equivalent of turning the clock forward almost seven or eight years, Gillen said.
Gillen said reports should show March as the company's best month on record in Florida.
The company completed its face-lift of the old Riverside signson Sept. 24, about five months after taking over the bank.
TD Bank has 15 teller locations throughout the Treasure Coast, and the company's green vans featuring marketing slogans such as Wow Zone and America's Most Convenient Bank have started to replace Riverside Bank (hearts) Con
Convenient Bank have started to replace Riverside Bank (hearts) Me bumper stickers along U.S. 1.
For many customers, the bank switch meant a trade of local connection for convenience, including extended hours on weekdays and weekends.
Fort Pierce resident Christina Garwood, 54, said she banked at Riverside for about a decade before the turnover. Garwood said TD Bank kept many of the same tellers she saw with Riverside.
The customer service is great, Garwood said. They take care of me. I go to see the same people, so it's good.
While many customers such as Garwood don't notice much of a difference, investors and former employees saw major transition.
For 25 years, some of the area's elite flocked to Riverside stock as one of the area's best investments. Shares initially selling for $10 a pop in 1982 went for more than $550 in 2008 while paying a large dividend. Those shares are now worthless.
Some Treasure Coast families had their entire life savings tied into Riverside, and when the company went under, so did those families' retirement funds.
That's very troubling for them and very troubling for anybody else associated with the bank, said Fort Pierce-based attorney Frank Speedy Fee. Fee represents Riverside National Bank's board of directors and bought shares from Riverside founder Vernon Smith in early 2007.
When bank stocks began to fall, Fee said he looked to sell his stake. But once he learned Riverside had problems, he pulled the stocks from the market.
I did not know what they were worth, and I wasn't going to sell them to somebody if I didn't think they were getting full value, Fee said.
Fee said he does not hold any ill feelings toward Smith despite the loss on the investment.
I've given him the benefit of the doubt as to what he knew or didn't know at that time because it was not until later in the year that events occurred that clearly spelled out a problem for Riverside, Fee said.
Others were not so quick to forgive.
On March 30, Indian River County residents R. William Becker and Mary Ann Becker sued Smith after he personally sold them $1 million in shares in 2008. According to the suit, Smith told the two the bank was in sound financial shape at the time of the purchase.
Smith did not return calls seeking comment, but in May, he told Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers that bank officials were totally above board and apologized for Riverside's failure. Smith said he felt badly for investors.
Absolutely, he said. I'm one of them. Obviously this was a real bad development, the way it worked out for all of us.
And that includes some employees.
Although TD Bank retained most of Riverside's 1,100 employees, the company cut 200 spots. Some of the employees were offered jobs elsewhere in the bank. TD Bank still is hiring on the Treasure Coast and expects to grow, Gillen said.
But for employees, the stress of uncertainty and for some eventual layoffs took a toll.
St. Lucie County Commission Chairman Chris Craft's wife, Patti, served as a vice president for Riverside for about five years before being offered a choice either to take a job in New Jersey or face termination a couple months after TD Bank took over. Given her husband's position, a move was not feasible.
She has since found a job at First Bank & Trust of Indiantown, but Chris Craft said the process was difficult. Bonuses amounting to 20 percent of pay disappeared before the takeover, Craft said. Patti and Chris Craft knew many local people within the banking world.
Just even seeing some of our friends who were also working at Riverside, and the anxiousness, the uncertainty of whether or not my job is going to be there when I get there tomorrow,' obviously it weighed on all of us, Chris Craft said.
Chris Craft said he gave up his 2010 U.S. congressional bid in part because of the stress at home, but the commissioner said he did not blame the bank's board for Riverside's failure.
There was great effort put forward by those folks, and they're good people, he said.
They also were people with close ties to the community. Riverside leaders made community involvement a core aspect of the company.
The bank sponsored both major and minor local events and charities such as local chapters for the United Way and Rotary Club. When TD Bank came, some were concerned the international bank would not participate as much in sponsorships, St. Lucie County Chamber of Commerce President Linda Cox said.
I would say it's always a fear, Cox said. We always worry about it, but so far, it hasn't held true. We've done pretty well.
TD Bank will serve as the title sponsor for the chamber's annual Fishing Frenzy in May and is a sponsor for Port St. Lucie's 50th anniversary celebration later this month.
Company representatives have visited several Treasure Coast classrooms to teach about money, and several of the company's Treasure Coast branches feature educational games for children. The learning activities are part of TD Bank's marketing focus on families.
Still, Ken Thomas, a Miami-based independent bank consultant and economist, said it's easier for a bank to be involved in the community where the bank's leadership lives.
When we lost Riverside National, we lost the entire tree, including the roots, and they were replaced with branches, Thomas said. But we hope that TD Bank does keep the same level of support to different causes that Riverside did because they are replacing a very important bank. Riverside had a very important place in the community.
TD BAnk: By the numbers
6th largest bank in North America, by branches
19 million overall customers
6.5 million U.S. customers
25,000 U.S. employees
160 Treasure Coast employees
1,400 Florida employees
200 open Florida positions
1,250 locations from Maine to Florida
$18.6 million given to U.S. charities, including $13 million from TD Charitable Foundation
Source: TD Bank 2010 Corporate Responsibility Report

TD Bank has made a concerted effort to be convenient. The bank's stores have longer hours than most competitors.

Riverside timeline
Here's a look at Riverside National Bank's history:
1982: Established in Fort Pierce by Vernon Smith as an independent, locally owned institution with 10 employees and an office in a trailer.
Sept. 2008: The bank had a 3 -star rating from BauerFinancial Inc. But lost $131 million in 2008.
2009: Had grown to 65 offices in 10 Florida counties, with more than 1,000 employees and $4.5 billion in assets by the time Smith retired. It was the largest bank in St. Lucie County, with a 24 percent market share.
Sept. 2009: Had zero-star rating from BauerFinancial Inc. Lost $131 million in 2009, although it made a profit in the fourth quarter.
January 2010: An agreement reached with the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta gave Riverside 60 days to submit an acceptable written plan to maintain sufficient capital.
April 16, 2010: Taken over by federal regulators and turned over to TD Bank.
Sept. 24, 2010: TD Bank officially puts up new signs and banners marking the company's start on the Treasure Coast.
CREDIT: Eric Pfahler

____________________________________________________________

Learning ABCs on iPads

Información de publicación: Kitsap Sun ; Bremerton, Wash. [Bremerton, Wash]. 13 Apr 2011: A.8.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/learning-abcs-on-ipads/docview/2574593600/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Learning+ABCs+on+iPads&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;date=2011-04-13&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Kitsap+Sun&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Awestnews_

Texto completo: PORTLAND, Maine Kindergarten classes are supplementing crayons, finger paints and flashcards with iPads, a development that excites supporters but that detractors worry is wasted on pupils too young to appreciate the expense.
Next fall, nearly 300 kindergartners in the central Maine city of Auburn will become the latest batch of youngsters around the country to get iPad2 touch pad tablets to learn the basics about ABCs, 1-2-3s, drawing and even music.
It's definitely an adventure, and it'll be a journey of learning for teachers and students, said Auburn kindergarten teacher Amy Heimerl, who received an iPad on Tuesday ahead of the full deployment in the fall. I'm looking forward to seeing where this can take us and our students.
But the $200,000 that Superintendent Tom Morrill is proposing to spend on iPads which retail for around $500 might be better spent on some other school program, said Sue Millard of Auburn, who has children in the fourth grade and high school. She also questions whether kindergartners are old enough to appreciate the effort.
I understand you have to keep up with technology, but I think a 5-year-old is a little too young to understand, she said.
Maine was the first state to equip students statewide with computers when it distributed Apple laptops to all seventh- and eighth-graders in 2002 and 2003. The program since has expanded, with laptops parceled out to about 50 percent of high school students.
The State Department of Education says it believes Auburn is the first school district in Maine that will give iPads to kindergartners. The school board last week unanimously approved the plan to give all kindergartners iPads next fall.
The iPad is a powerful education tool with hundreds of teaching applications, Morrill said. With its touch pad screen, it's simple to use and can bring learning to life with imagery and sounds, he said.

Materia: Preschool education; Students; Portable computers; Learning

Lugar: United States--US Maine

Título: Learning ABCs on iPads

Título de publicación: Kitsap Sun; Bremerton, Wash.

Año de publicación: 2011

Sección: Wire

Editorial: Gannett Co Inc

Lugar de publicación: Bremerton, Wash.

Kindergartners to learn ABCs, iPads

Autor: Canfield, Clarke.

Información de publicación: Corpus Christi Caller - Times ; Corpus Christi [Corpus Christi]. 13 Apr 2011: A.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/kindergartners-learn-abcs-ipads/docview/2569356441/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Kindergartners+to+learn+ABCs%2C+iPads&amp;author=Canfield%2C+Clarke&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;date=2011-04-13&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Corpus+Christi+Caller+-+Times&amp;issn=0894-5365&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: PORTLAND, Maine Kindergarten classes are supplementing crayons, finger paints and flashcards with iPads, a development that excites supporters but that detractors worry is wasted on pupils too young to appreciate the expense.
Next fall, nearly 300 kindergartners in the central Maine city of Auburn will become the latest batch of youngsters around the country to get iPad2 touch pad tablets to learn the basics about ABCs, 1-2-3s, drawing and even music.
It's definitely an adventure, and it'll be a journey of learning for teachers and students, said Auburn kindergarten teacher Amy Heimerl, who received an iPad on Tuesday ahead of the full deployment in the fall. I'm looking forward to seeing where this can take us and our students.
But the $200,000 that Superintendent Tom Morrill is proposing to spend on iPads which retail for around $500 might be better spent on some other school program, said Sue Millard of Auburn, who has children in the fourth grade and high school. She also questions whether kindergartners are old enough to appreciate the effort.
I understand you have to keep up with technology, but I think a 5-year-old is a little too young to understand, she said.
Maine was the first state to equip students statewide with computers when it distributed Apple laptops to all seventh- and eighth-graders in 2002 and 2003. The program since has expanded, with laptops parceled out to about 50 percent of high school students.
The State Department of Education says it believes Auburn is the first school district in Maine that will give iPads to kindergartners. The school board last week unanimously approved the plan to give all kindergartners iPads next fall.
The iPad is a powerful education tool with hundreds of teaching applications, Morrill said. With its touch pad screen, it's simple to use and can bring learning to life with imagery and sounds, he said.

____________________________________________________________

Documentary had audience thinking about decline, consumption of fish

Información de publicación: The Stuart News ; Stuart, Fla. [Stuart, Fla]. 12 Apr 2011: B.3.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/documentary-had-audience-thinking-about-decline/docview/2607242520/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Documentary+had+audience+thinking+about+decline%2C+consumption+of+fish&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.3&amp;date=2011-04-12&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Stuart+News&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: VERO BEACH Many of the 55 people watching the award-winning documentary The End of the Line, Sunday night said they'd re-examine their fish consumption.
The 2009 film, screened by the Social Justice committee of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship Church of Vero Beach on Sunday evening, described how ocean fish populations, once renewable, are no longer renewable due to overfishing by commercial fisherman.
Rita Maier, whose family comes from a fishing background in Maine, said she was aware of the problem. Twenty years ago, she had family members who had to stop fishing off the coast of Maine because of the dwindling population, and, instead, fish off the coast of Canada.
The film, directed by Rupert Murray and narrated by Ted Danson, is based on the book, The End of the Line by Charles Clover.
The film chronicled the sharp decline of the bluefin tuna caused by increasing demand for sushi.
The documentary went on to highlight how regulations were not well-received by fisherman in other parts of the world, but touched on how a 250-mile commercial fishing area in Alaska is being well-received by commercial fisherman. Alaskan fisherman in the documentary said the restrictions would allow the population to grow over time allowing their catches to be more plentiful in the long term.
Nancy Stiefel, a member of the Social Justice Committee and of the church, said the film series started in 2006 when the church received a copy of the Al Gore film An Inconvenient Truth. When the church showed the film, turnout was good, so now a Social Justice Film Committee shows films once a month from September through June.
Stiefel said the next film, the documentary, For the Bible Tells Me So, is scheduled for May 1.
CREDIT: Geoff Madore

Materia: Social justice; Documentary films; Commercial fishing

Título: Documentary had audience thinking about decline, consumption of fish

Countdown to the Civil War

Información de publicación: Asheville Citizen - Times ; Asheville, N.C. [Asheville, N.C]. 11 Apr 2011: A.4.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/countdown-civil-war/docview/1471248157/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Dozens of slaves are executed. 1846 The Wilmot Proviso, defeated in the U.S. Senate, would have banned slavery in any territory acquired during the Mexican-American War. 1850 The Compromise of 1850 admits California, including areas below the Missouri Compromise line, as a free state; New Mexico, Nevada, Arizona and Utah may decide about slavery when applying for statehood; selling slaves is prohibited in the District of Columbia; and the Fugitive Slave Act passes. 1854 The Kansas-Nebraska Act creates the Kansas and Nebraska territories, allowing their residents to decide about slavery. 1857 In Dred Scott v. Sandford, the U.S. Supreme Court led by Chief Justice Roger Taney rules that a slave is not a citizen of the United States and therefore is not protected by the Constitution.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Countdown+to+the+Civil+War&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;date=2011-04-11&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asheville+Citizen+-+Times&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo:   Some key events in U.S. history that led to the War Bewteen the States:
1820
The Missouri Compromise preserves the balance of power in Congress between free and slave states. Missouri is admitted to the union as a slave state; Maine as a free state. The law also bans slavery in the Louisiana Territory north of the 36 degrees 30 minutes latitude line.
1831
Nat Turner, a Virginia slave, leads a rebellion that frees more than 70 slaves and leaves 55 whites dead. He is captured and hanged. Dozens of slaves are executed.
1846
The Wilmot Proviso, defeated in the U.S. Senate, would have banned slavery in any territory acquired during the Mexican-American War.
1850
The Compromise of 1850 admits California, including areas below the Missouri Compromise line, as a free state; New Mexico, Nevada, Arizona and Utah may decide about slavery when applying for statehood; selling slaves is prohibited in the District of Columbia; and the Fugitive Slave Act passes.
1854
The Kansas-Nebraska Act creates the Kansas and Nebraska territories, allowing their residents to decide about slavery.
1857
In Dred Scott v. Sandford, the U.S. Supreme Court led by Chief Justice Roger Taney rules that a slave is not a citizen of the United States and therefore is not protected by the Constitution. The ruling also says Congress does not have the authority to prohibit slavery in the territories.
1858
Abraham Lincoln and Sen. Stephen Douglas hold seven debates during the campaign for the Illinois Senate seat. Lincoln loses the election.
1859
Oct. 16: Abolitionist John Brown attacks federal arsenal at Harper's Ferry, Va. (now West Virginia.)
1860
Feb. 22: In a speech at Cooper Union in New York, Lincoln denounces the Kansas-Nebraska Act and Dred Scott decision.
May 16: Republican Party nominates Lincoln for president.
Nov. 6: Lincoln is first Republican elected president.
Dec. 20: South Carolina is first state to secede from the Union.
1861
States begin to secede: Mississippi (Jan. 9), Florida (Jan. 10), Alabama (Jan. 11), Georgia (Jan. 19), Texas (Feb. 1).
Feb. 9: Seceded states form Confederate States of America. Mississippi Sen. Jefferson Davis elected president and commander in chief.
March 4: Lincoln is inaugurated . In his Inaugural Address, Lincoln says he has no plans to end slavery in states where it already exists, but he will not accept secession.
April 12: Fort Sumter in Charleston, S.C., harbor is fired upon. Maj. Robert Anderson surrenders after 34 hours of bombardment, which produce no casualties.
April 15: Lincoln calls for a militia of 75,000 men.
More states secede: Virginia (April 17), Arkansas (May 6).
April 18: West Point graduate Robert E. Lee, a Virginian, is offered command of all Union forces. He declines.
April 19: Lincoln orders blockade of Southern ports.
April 20: Lee resigns his commission in U.S. Army.
April 23: Lee is appointed chief military adviser to Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy.
May 20: North Carolina secedes.
Compiled by Joan Murphy and Gary Rawlins, USA TODAY
Sources: Smithsonian Institution; National Park Service; World Book Encyclopedia; USA TODAY research

Materia: American Civil War; Presidents; Colonies & territories; Congressional elections

Lugar: Missouri Maine California Kansas Virginia United States--US

Personas: Scott, Dred (1795?-1858)

Empresa/organización: Nombre: Congress; NAICS: 921120; Nombre: Senate; NAICS: 921120; Nombre: Republican Party; NAICS: 813940; Nombre: Supreme Court-US; NAICS: 922110

____________________________________________________________

The war's start? Try looking in Maine

Autor: Werland, Ross.

Información de publicación: Chicago Tribune ; Chicago, Ill. [Chicago, Ill]. 10 Apr 2011: 5.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/wars-start-try-looking-maine/docview/861136515/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee turned Gettysburg into the grandest Civil War site in the North by invading Union territory in an in-your-face assault on Lincoln's army.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=The+war%27s+start%3F+Try+looking+in+Maine&amp;author=Werland%2C+Ross&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=5&amp;date=2011-04-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Chicago+Tribune&amp;issn=1085-6706&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Achicagotribune_

Texto completo: Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee turned Gettysburg into the grandest Civil War site in the North by invading Union territory in an in-your-face assault on Lincoln's army. That piece of rural Pennsylvania remains an awesome historical gut punch. It is not, however, the only significant Civil War site in the North.
It could be argued that the war started in this far North college town. Here Harriet Beecher Stowe wrote "Uncle Tom's Cabin," inspired by a sermon in a church that still stands at the corner of Maine Street and Bath Road: the First Parish Church.
Though historians disagree about whether Abraham Lincoln ever actually said, "So this is the little lady who started the great war" upon greeting her at the White House, her book had a nation-bending impact. Stowe's novel about the realities of slavery helped jell abolitionist opinion leading up to the war.
Just across the street from that Brunswick church is the home of a young Bowdoin College professor who would become one of the greatest heroes of Gettysburg, repelling fierce Confederate assaults. The Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain home is now a museum (207-729-6606, community.curtislibrary.com/pejepscot.htm) at 226 Maine St. The house escaped destruction in the 1980s and now has been smartly restored.
The shock for a visitor is that you might get there and find the museum closed. Check ahead. In this year, the 150th anniversary of the war's start, the museum doesn't open until May 24. It's also closed Sundays and Mondays.
Those significant sites aside, heading south out of town, you'll see how legacies aren't always what one might hope. There stands the Uncle Tom's Market, probably not the sort of commercial establishment Mrs. Stowe would have gloried in.
Then again, it's only 10 minutes to Freeport, which is a shopper's paradise, including the huge home of L.L. Bean. No worry about the hours there: Bean is always open (800-441-5713, llbean.com/llb/shop/1000001704).
Credit: Ross Werland, Tribune Newspapers
Illustration Caption: Photo (color): It's not the only trace of Harriet Beecher Stowe in Brunswick, Maine. ROSS WERLAND/TRIBUNE NEWSPAPERS

Materia: Travel; American Civil War; Black history; Historic buildings & sites; Tourism -- Maine

Lugar: Maine

Título: The war's start? Try looking in Maine

Autor: Werland, Ross

Título de publicación: Chicago Tribune; Chicago, Ill.

Páginas: 5.5

Año de publicación: 2011

Fecha de publicación: Apr 10, 2011

Lugar y fecha de origen: BRUNSWICK, Maine

Sección: Travel

Editorial: Tribune Publishing Company, LLC

Lugar de publicación: Chicago, Ill.

País de publicación: United States, Chicago, Ill.

Materia de publicación: General Interest Periodicals--United States

ISSN: 10 856706

Idioma de la publicación: English

____________________________________________________________

Showing cats easier than herding them

Información de publicación: The Commercial Appeal ; Memphis, Tenn. [Memphis, Tenn]. 10 Apr 2011: B.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/showing-cats-easier-than-herding-them/docview/2595321606/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Showing+cats+easier+than+herding+them&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;date=2011-04-10&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Commercial+Appeal&amp;issn=0745-4856&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: She would have made her father, Pabst Blue Ribbon, very proud.
Anheuser Bee performed onstage like a master pianist playing Moonlight Sonata Saturday at the Cat Fanciers Associations 20th annual cat show in Memphis.
The 8-year-old purebred Birman won over many a judges heart on the display table, and owner James Watson said he plans to hit up a few more shows before the seasons end . With enough points, Bee could land one of the coveted regional champion titles.
About 200 cats strutted their stuff in a showroom at Agricenter International, climbing scratching posts and swatting at feathers. A variety of breeds were represented, from Himalayan, Persian and Maine Coon to Cornish Rex and Siamese.
This is not really a big show, but there are some beautiful cats here, said Liz Watson, a judge and breeder. The quality at smaller shows is typically very consistent. The long-haired champions were very pretty.
Watson breeds Russian Blues and the hairless Sphynx, one of the more unusual-looking and expensive breeds. Prices for a show-quality Sphynx begin in the $2,000 range. Only one Sphynx was registered this weekend, so 21-year-old owner Olivia El-Awady bagged first place at her first show with 10-month-old Omorfosgatos Bucking Bronco.
I got one (Sphynx) as a pet, and then I got Bronco to begin breeding, said El-Awady, a neuroscience major at the University of Iowa . I like the Sphynx personality; its like part monkey, part child, part dog.
Spectators watched as judges made their rounds, taking each cat out of its cage and examining its traits.
I feel a silky fur, a sea of shaggy coat, one judge murmured while handling a Maine Coon. This cat is groomed to perfection.
But achieving that perfection takes time, said Cindy Steadham, holding her Exotic Shorthair named Beetlejuice, aka Juicy.
It took Steadham nearly two hours to give Juicy his show bath and finish his fur with a metro blow dryer. The 2-year-old brown-spotted tabby started to shake in Steadhams arms as a swarm of onlookers asked for pictures with the orange-eyed beauty.
Hes just being shy, Steadham said. But at home hes a ham, real rambunctious.
The cat show runs today from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is $6 for adults, $4 for children.
Sara Patterson: 529-2542
CREDIT: Sara Patterson patterson@commercialappeal.com

____________________________________________________________

Walker is larger-than-life celebrity of feline world

Información de publicación: The Commercial Appeal ; Memphis, Tenn. [Memphis, Tenn]. 07 Apr 2011: B.1.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/walker-is-larger-than-life-celebrity-feline-world/docview/2594507456/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Walker+is+larger-than-life+celebrity+of+feline+world&amp;author=&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;date=2011-04-07&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Commercial+Appeal&amp;issn=0745-4856&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo: The Texan is a big guest star with one of the busiest travel itineraries in the country, but he likes to drink from hotel room toilets.
When he arrives in Memphis for his latest guest appearance, at Agricenter International, it will be as a guest of honor with a national title wholl give admirers a chance to cuddle him.
Meet Walker, a 25-pound Maine Coon cat from Richmond, Texas, one of the main attractions when the Mid South Cat Fanciers hold their 20th annual show Saturday and Sunday.
Walker was the winner at the 2010 Meet the Breeds showcase of dogs and cats in New York, and he will be on hand to be photographed and held during the Agricenter show and competition, called Spring Fling.
Eight-year-old Walker won what amounts to a beauty contest when he was chosen by audience acclaim at the New York show, said Alvin Green, president of the Mid South Cat Fanciers. Walker beat out an American shorthair cat and an exotic shorthair cat in what was billed the Iams Cat Idol competition.
Green said the Maine Coon cat is the largest domestic cat breed, but Walker is exceptional. Most Maine Coons weigh in the teens up to about 20 pounds. They are hardly ever his size. To see a video of Walker winning his competition, go to .
His owner, orthodontic assistant Donna Hinton, has traveled to dozens of cities with Walker and said she has learned that nationally recognized show cats have quirks that set them apart as much as their breeding . Walker is able to lift split toilet seats with his nose and likes to drink from the toilet in his hotel room. He also likes to rummage through her purse for makeup sponges which he likes to bat around on the hotel room floor.
The Agricenter Show will include between 150 and 200 cats competing in adult, kitten and fixed-cat categories, Green said. In the shows long history, he said a cat has never escaped or run away. If one gets loose, we close the doors and catch them right away.
The shows are 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday and 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sunday. Admission is $6 for adults and $4 for children.
CREDIT: Michael Lollar lollar@commercialappeal.com

____________________________________________________________

Builders rally against efforts to weaken state code

Autor: TURKEL, TUX.

Información de publicación: Portland Press Herald ; Portland, Me. [Portland, Me]. 06 Apr 2011: n/a.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/builders-rally-against-efforts-weaken-state-code/docview/860223015/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: John O'Dea, president of the Associated General Contractors of Maine Homebuilders, engineers and contractors gathered at the State House on Tuesday to protest attempts to gut or eliminate Maine's Uniform Building and Energy Code, which was adopted last year.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Builders+rally+against+efforts+to+weaken+state+code%3A+They+say+the+standard+helps+Maine%27s+business+climate+and+saves+energy.&amp;author=TURKEL%2C+TUX&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.3&amp;date=2011-04-06&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Portland+Press+Herald&amp;issn=2689-5900&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo: Note: "Having a single code for Maine makes it so much easier to do commercial development in the state. We want the governor and legislators to know that this is a positive form of regulation because these are very achievable, measurable standards." John O'Dea, president of the Associated General Contractors of Maine
Homebuilders, engineers and contractors gathered at the State House on Tuesday to protest attempts to gut or eliminate Maine's Uniform Building and Energy Code, which was adopted last year.
Maine's code is similar to those in 40 other states. Several pieces of legislation have been drafted to repeal or weaken it, including L.D. 43, "An Act to Repeal the Maine Uniform Building and Energy Code." That bill is scheduled for a public hearing Thursday before the Legislature's Labor Committee.
The businesses that joined in Tuesday's protest called on Gov. Paul LePage and legislators to oppose any rollbacks. They said the code improves Maine's business climate, reduces energy costs and improves the quality and safety of new homes and commercial buildings.
Speakers provided copies of a letter to LePage signed by some of Maine's leading building trade associations, representing more than 1,500 businesses.
John O'Dea, president of the Associated General Contractors of Maine, said the code is good for business.
"Having a single code for Maine makes it so much easier to do commercial development in the state," he said. "We want the governor and legislators to know that this is a positive form of regulation because these are very achievable, measurable standards."
The state is training and certifying code enforcement officials and third-party inspectors who can certify compliance in towns that choose not to hire municipal code officials. Towns that did not previously have building codes have until July 2012 to choose some method of enforcement.
A new analysis of costs and benefits of the energy portion of the code was described by Ashley Richards, a builder and insulation contractor from Yarmouth. He said the incremental cost of building to the code is less than $3,000, and the code creates net savings through energy reductions starting with the first monthly payment.
Staff Writer Tux Turkel can be contacted at 791-6462 or at:
tturkel@pressherald.com
Credit: By TUX TURKEL Staff Writer

Materia: Industrial development; Cost control; Legislators; Bills; Home building; Building codes

Lugar: Maine

Clasificación: 9190: United States; 8370: Construction & engineering industry; 4310: Regulation

____________________________________________________________

Former Pleasant Point police chief pleads guilty to thefts that supported gambling habit

Autor: Sharon Kiley Mack.

Información de publicación: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]. 06 Apr 2011.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/former-pleasant-point-police-chief-pleads-guilty/docview/1506096495/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: According to Robbin, in October 2007 Barnes withdrew $2,400 from an ATM at a Louisiana casino, just days after a $10,000 check from an ESPN executive was diverted from a tribal charity into the soda account.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Former+Pleasant+Point+police+chief+pleads+guilty+to+thefts+that+supported+gambling+habit&amp;author=Sharon+Kiley+Mack&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;date=2011-04-06&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;issn=0892-8738&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Anortheastnews1_

Texto completo:   MACHIAS, Maine -- Former Pleasant Point Police Chief Joseph Barnes, 42, pleaded guilty Wednesday in Washington County Superior Court to felony theft charges involving more than $33,244 that he took from Passamaquoddy Tribal accounts between April 2007 and May 2008.
Assistant Attorney General Leanne Robbin said Barnes used the money to feed a gambling habit at casinos in both Connecticut and Louisiana, and avoided tribal and U.S. Department of Interior investigations for months.
His police career destroyed and his reputation shattered, Barnes sobbed through much of Wednesday's proceeding. His attorney said he was under the care of a mental health counselor and Barnes' sentencing was postponed until June 9 because of his tenuous emotional state.
Robbin explained that Barnes, who was an honored and decorated police chief, began funneling thousands of dollars into a so-called soda account, and then "frittered it all away" at Foxwoods Casino in Connecticut and another casino in Marksville, La.
Robbin said Barnes refused to answer questions when the tribe's chief financial officer discovered that thousands of dollars were suddenly being deposited in the small soda account, supported by a vending machine in the police station. Those deposits then were being withdrawn by Barnes, either through automatic teller machines at casinos, or checks written out to cash.
After being confronted in May 2009, Barnes resigned as the police chief and did not provide tribal leaders with an exit interview.
According to Robbin, in October 2007 Barnes withdrew $2,400 from an ATM at a Louisiana casino, just days after a $10,000 check from an ESPN executive was diverted from a tribal charity into the soda account. The check was intended to purchase three permits for moose hunts for the ESPN executive on tribal lands.
Other money deposited in the soda account came from the state of Maine for reimbursements for services, for a Maine Drug Enforcement Agency officer, and tribal warden funds.
Throughout the investigation, Barnes claimed the money went toward paying off confidential informants and supplying cash prizes to various charities. Robbin said Barnes could provide no documentation of that.
Robbin said most of the checks deposited were addressed to the Pleasant Point Police Department but should have been deposited in the tribal general fund as revenues. The investigation was triggered by tribal leaders and involved the U.S. Department of the Interior and the Maine Attorney General's Office.
"We discovered there was a correlation between withdrawals made by Mr. Barnes and trips he made to casinos," Robbin said. She said Barnes stopped using an ATM at one point and began writing checks to cash for $200, $500 and $750. The withdrawals stopped in May 2008, she said, "because there was no more money and the tribe was left with overdraft fees."
Wednesday's hearing took place just one day before jury selection was to begin for Barnes' trial. He pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor of misuse of entrusted funds and a felony charge of theft by unauthorized taking.
A pre-sentence investigation was requested by Barnes' attorney Jeff Davidson, who said he expects to call several witnesses at the sentencing hearing.
Justice E. Allen Hunter set June 9 as a sentencing date.
Robbin said the state will be asking for a four-year prison sentence with all but one year suspended and restitution.
Barnes, who served as a police officer for more than 20 years, was in his 20s when he was appointed police chief at Pleasant Point in 1992, the youngest on the reservation. In 2000, the Maine Criminal Justice Academy in Waterville certified Barnes as a police chief. He was the first American Indian in the state to receive such certification.
Barnes in 2006 received the Chief of Police of the Year Award from the National Native American Law Enforcement Association, the first for a Maine American Indian police chief. In 2000 Barnes, working with the Maine Drug Enforcement Agency, helped deal a blow to the prescription drug problem on the reservation when a covert operation led to the arrest of some 15 people. Three years later, the Maine Drug Enforcement Agency presented Barnes and former tribal investigator Robert Dore with the distinguished Maine Drug Task Force Service Award.
Credit: Sharon Kiley Mack BDN Staff

____________________________________________________________

Maine's blunt-talking governor rankles voters Hardscrabble life may account for what he says

Autor: Canfield, Clarke.

Información de publicación: Abilene Reporter-News ; Abilene [Abilene]. 04 Apr 2011: A.5.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/maines-blunt-talking-governor-rankles-voters/docview/2560983164/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Maine%27s+blunt-talking+governor+rankles+voters+Hardscrabble+life+may+account+for+what+he+says&amp;author=Canfield%2C+Clarke&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;date=2011-04-04&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Abilene+Reporter-News&amp;issn=0199-3267&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asouthcentralnews_

Texto completo: AUGUSTA, Maine With less than three months on the job, Gov. Paul LePage has already managed to rankle more constituencies with his bluntness than any Maine governor in recent memory.
Even before he was elected, LePage said he'd tell the president to go to hell. Two weeks after taking office, he called the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People a special interest group and told critics to kiss my butt over his decision to not attend the NAACP's annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day celebrations.
He later raised a ruckus when he dismissed the dangers of bisphenol-A, a chemical additive used in some plastic bottles, saying the worst that could happen was some women may have little beards.
Now he's ticking off labor groups and smaller constituencies such as artists and museum curators, which typically aren't on anybody's political radar screen by removing a huge mural depicting the state's labor history from the Labor Department headquarters because it wasn't in keeping with his pro-business agenda. When asked what he would do if anybody tried to block the mural's removal, he said, I'd laugh at them, the idiots.
You could draw up a pretty extensive list of various constituencies across the state that Gov. LePage has managed to offend in one way or another, said Mark Brewer, a political science professor at the University of Maine. And the fact that he's been in office for only a few months makes the size of that list all the more impressive.
Nobody expected a polished, spit-and-shine governor when LePage, a Republican, was elected in November. The oldest son in an impoverished family of 18 children in blue-collar Lewiston, he left home before he was a teenager to escape domestic violence. He shined shoes and sold newspapers while sleeping at friends' homes, in horse stables and even in an upstairs room at a strip joint.
With his tell-it-like-it-is attitude and his aim of shaking up state government, it's inevitable LePage will anger certain people. The governor speaks what's on his mind, said spokeswoman Adrienne Bennett.
It's his policies and the substance that people should be focusing on, Bennett said. Whether or not he gets style points is not high on our priority list.
You'd have to go back to James Longley, an independent who served from 1975-79, to find anything close to the spiciness coming from LePage, said Kenneth Palmer, who has written several books on Maine politics and taught at the University of Maine from 1969-2004.
Longley could be abrasive and once called some legislators pimps, but it was his ideology not his off-the-cuff remarks that most angered his critics, he said.
On the whole, Maine governors have been fairly straight-laced and moderate, Palmer said.
It's hard to say if LePage's style is hurting him politically, said MaryEllen FitzGerald, president of the Critical Insights market research firm in Portland.
LePage's brusqueness may be energizing his detractors, but it may also be invigorating his supporters, FitzGerald said.
Depending on which side of the fence you're on, you see him as being either very insensitive and careless, or you see him as being a pretty effective strategist, she said.

Materia: Governors

Lugar: United States--US Maine

____________________________________________________________

Spring arrives, and Appalachian Trail activity hits high gear

Autor: Neal, Dale.

Información de publicación: Asheville Citizen - Times ; Asheville, N.C. [Asheville, N.C]. 03 Apr 2011: A.10.

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/spring-arrives-appalachian-trail-activity-hits/docview/1471242381/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: A survey by the club and the Appalachian Trail Conservancy found that the average thru-hikers stopping off in Franklin spent $153 in town for an estimated $38,339 impact on area hotels and businesses.

Enlaces: https://upfinder.upf.edu/openurl/34CSUC_UPF/34CSUC_UPF:VU1?genre=article&amp;atitle=Spring+arrives%2C+and+Appalachian+Trail+activity+hits+high+gear&amp;author=Neal%2C+Dale&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;date=2011-04-03&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.jtitle=Asheville+Citizen+-+Times&amp;issn=&amp;isbn=&amp;sid=ProQ%3Asoutheastnews_

Texto completo:   Former S.C. Gov. Mark Sanford nearly screwed it up for the rest of us. When I told my wife that I was going hiking for a few days on the Appalachian Trial, she didn't automatically think I was headed to Argentina for a wild fling with a mistress.
She knew I was out on a date with my adoring dog, Pearl, the golden Lab. Pearl and I packed up for a southerly jaunt along the AT through the Southern Nantahala Wilderness. But we weren't alone. I wanted to see the annual migration of thru-hikers who start out about this time of year from Springer Mountain, Ga., with Maine on their minds.
In three days, Pearl and I passed about 50 folks working their way north with heavy packs and trekking poles.
Each year, more than 2 million people walk part of the Appalachian Trail, but only a die-hard few dare to hike the whole 2,179 miles from Springer up to Mount Katahdin in Maine. Last year, 1,460 thru-hikers signed in at Springer. Their numbers were whittled down to 747 by the midway point at 1,013 miles at Harpers Ferry, Va., and only 349 made it all the way to Katahdin by the season's end.
Pearl with her pack got petted by plenty of hikers we met in our journey. We would catch our breath every quarter-mile or so, talking with the next hiker about the weather or how far the next shelter and water was. They came in all ages and sizes and both sexes, from college-age guys to grizzled seniors. There were German exchange students and a New Englander given his accent, trying to head not just back toward home, but to the next shelter and the promise of a dry night ahead.
Trucking along the AT changes people, who take on trail names for the duration.
"Savage" hailed from Augusta, Ga., a polite kid despite his trail name, who had the disconcerting habit of calling me "sir." We chatted as we caught our breath atop 5,085-foot Albert Mountain with its long views east toward Franklin and Dillard, Ga.
"Crux" snuck up on me at the spring at Mooney's Gap about dusk. He had only been out for five days, which meant he was logging about 20 miles a day. "Yeah, I've been moving along," he said over his shoulder, already trucking up the trail.
A gray-haired guy with a black knee brace was climbing up the trail the next morning.
"Where you headed?"
"The next shelter," he huffed. "Maine, maybe."
"How long you been out here?"
"Don't ask. I'm a turtle," he replied.
With about 100 miles already under their cinched hip belts, many of these hikers were headed to Winding Stairs Gap to catch a free shuttle for the 11-mile ride down U.S. 64 to Franklin. Designated an Appalachian Trail Community just last year, Franklin is trying to make itself into a hiker-friendly destination, according to Bill Van Horn of the Nantahala Hiking Club.
A survey by the club and the Appalachian Trail Conservancy found that the average thru-hikers stopping off in Franklin spent $153 in town for an estimated $38,339 impact on area hotels and businesses. They may look rough and disheveled, but many thru-hikers come with higher incomes. The survey found 19 percent made between $40,000 and $60,000 annually and another 19 percent topped out above $60,000. They were also better-educated with 48 percent carrying bachelor's degrees and 12 percent with master's. It doesn't take a Ph.D. to hike the AT, but about 4 percent of the surveyed trekkers had doctorates.
In their annual migration, trekkers are spending money from Wesser to Hot Springs along North Carolina's 280 miles and at rural outposts through 13 other states along the AT. Franklin wants to join that crowd.
"We're trying to capitalize on how close we are to the trail and make sure the hikers get a good feeling for Franklin," Van Horn said. "They might want to come back with their families."
After days of camaraderie on the AT, Pearl and I had the whole four miles of the Long Ridge Trail to ourselves as we descended 2,000 feet to Standing Indian campground for a 21-mile loop.
By now, Savage might be saying "sir" to folks in Hot Springs. Turtle might be crawling through the Smokies. Crux might be closing in on Damascus, Va.
But I still didn't come across Gov. Sanford.
Contact Neal at DNeal@CITIZEN-TIMES.com.
Dale
Neal
OPINION

Materia: Trails; Camping equipment

Briefly

Información de publicación: The Commercial Appeal ; Memphis, Tenn. [Memphis, Tenn]. 02 Apr 2011: A.4.

Texto completo: California
Serial killer gets life sentences
LOS ANGELES A former state insurance adjuster pleaded guilty Friday to killing seven women and was sentenced to life in prison for a series of deadly sexual attacks by a man known by police as the Westside Rapist.
John Floyd Thomas, 74, pleaded guilty to seven counts of first-degree murder and was sentenced to seven life terms, including one without the possibility of parole in the attacks that terrified Los Angeles County in the 1970s and 1980s, Los Angeles County district attorneys spokeswoman Sandi Gibbons said.
Arizona
Tucson shooting victim honored
ORO VALLEY A 9-foot, 11-inch-tall silver statue of an angel just beyond the outfield fence was unveiled Friday, honoring Christina-Taylor Green, the youngest victim of the Tucson shootings.
Its going to serve as a daily reminder to us that we had the privilege of knowing Christina, said John Ward, who coached her for two years in Canyon del Oro Little League.
The angels hand extends out, its robes appearing to blow in the wind. It is intended as a symbol of comfort after the Jan. 8 shooting that killed five others and wounded 13, including Rep. Gabrielle Giffords.
New England
Snowstorm hits on April Fools
PORTLAND, Maine An April Fools Day storm brought heavy snowfall to parts of New England on Friday, creating a late-season winter wonderland that sent scores of cars sliding off roads, knocked out power for thousands and gave kids a surprise reprieve from school.
Falling tree limbs knocked out electricity for nearly 60,000 homes and businesses in Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Rhode Island at the storms peak, officials said. Scores of cars and trucks slid off roads, but there were no reports of serious injuries.
Snapshots
Malcolm X scholar dies: An influential scholar of the black experience in the United States and the author of a forthcoming biography of Malcolm X has died in New York City. Manning Marable was 60. Marables latest book, Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention, will be published Monday.
Medicaid considers tax on smokers, obese: Arizonas cash-strapped Medicaid program is considering charging patients $50 a year if they smoke, have diabetes or are overweight. A spokeswoman for the Arizona Health Care Cost Containment System says the tax is intended to push patients to take better care of themselves. The fee would only apply to childless, unmarried adults.
Plane diverted after passengers faint: Two flight attendants reported dizziness and four passengers fainted aboard an American Airlines flight Friday, forcing the pilot to drop the jets oxygen masks and land in Dayton, Ohio, an airline spokesman said. Two passengers and a flight attendant were taken to hospitals, but their conditions were not known.
Migrants escape Italian tent camp: Hundreds of North African immigrants fled from a camp in southern Italy on Friday. The migrants had been transferred from the overcrowded island of Lampedusa into a tent camp in the southern Italian town of Manduria. Some 22,000 people, mostly from Tunisia, have arrived on this tiny Italian island since the start of the year. Premier Silvio Berlusconi called the migration wave brought about by unrest across North Africa a human tsunami.
Quake strikes Crete: A strong earthquake struck the southern Greek island of Crete Friday, rattling buildings as far away as Egypt and Turkey. Local police said they had no reports of damage or injuries. The quake had a preliminary magnitude of 6.2.
Portugal raises $2.3 billion: Debt-stressed Portugal got some respite from its financial troubles Friday when it managed to borrow $2.3 billion in a bond auction. However, the money it raised didnt come cheap amid widespread expectations that Portugal will soon have to join Greece and Ireland in requesting a bailout. The government debt agency said its paying a 5.8 percent interest rate on the bonds, which mature in June 2012.
Poland rules out terrorist attack: The April 2010 plane crash that killed Polish Pesident Lech Kaczynski and 95 others was not caused by any kind of terrorist attack, Polish military prosecutors said Friday. There are no reasons to suspect a terrorist attack, said Col. Ireneusz Szelag, head of the district prosecutors office Friday, citing multiple studies commissioned by authorities.
L.A. mayor to be fined: Californias campaign finance watchdog on Friday recommended the largest combined fine in the agencys history more than $40,000 against Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa, saying he failed to report free tickets to dozens of sporting and entertainment events, ranging from the finals of American Idol to Los Angeles Lakers games.
CREDIT: From Our Press Services

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/obituaries/docview/2573950444/se-2?accountid=14708

Resumen: Ninguno disponible.

Texto completo: Gloria Ann Basher
of Bremerton
Dec. 5, 1937
to March 17, 2011
Gloria Ann Basher was born to Marvin and Della Perrin 12-5-1937. She graduated from West Seattle High School and married Fred Basher in 1956.
Gloria's mother, father, and husband preceded her in death. She is survived by her brother and sister, two daughters and four grandchildren.
Gloria Ann died peacefully in her sleep 3-17-2011 in her home in Bremerton, WA.
In lieu of flowers the family asks that donations be given to charity. Please sign the online guest book at:www.tuellmckeebremerton.com
Richard D. Andersen
of Port Orchard
Nov. 4, 1929
to March 27, 2011
Richard gently passed away Sunday March 27th due to complications after lung surgery. He was born in Salt Lake City, Utah on November 4, 1929 to Viggo and Myrl Andersen.
He joined the Navy at age 17, married in 1951 and had two children, Rick and Vickie. He retired from the Navy in 1966 and relocated to Port Orchard, Wa. He divorced and remarried Carol Lierman of Port Orchard in 1978.
He worked 25 years for the Kitsap County Road Department, retiring as Road Supervisor of the South End Road Shed in 1991. He loved country music, reading, gardening, crosswords and last but not least his dog, Bogie.
He was preceded in death by brothers, Gerald and Robert, sisters Lillian, Myrtle and Betty and grandson Leif Erickson. He is survived by his wife Carol, his sister Elsie Howard of Kearns, Utah, son Rick Andersen of Belfair, daughter Vickie Lynch of Gig Harbor, stepsons Marc Lane of Salem, Or., and Carl Lierman of Seattle, Wa., stepdaughters Kim Graziano and Rebecca Lane both of Port Orchard, Wa., five grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.
There will be no service at his request. A family memorial will be held at a later date. He will be greatly missed.
Thomas E. Kiso
of Port Orchard
Sept. 8, 1942
to March 11, 2011
On March 11, 2011, Thomas Kiso passed away peacefully in his home in Port Orchard, WA after a brief illness.
Tom was born on Sept. 8, 1942, to Albert and Elinor (Thornton) Kiso in Tacoma, WA. He grew up in Eatonville and Mineral and graduated from Morton H.S. in 1961. After high school, Tom enlisted in the U.S. Navy, where he trained as a dental technician.
In later years, he successfully owned and operated his own dental lab, Crafty Hands, in Port Orchard, WA. Tom was a gifted craftsman who loved music, sailing, wooden boats, geography and politics, and was a wealth of facts, information and often passionate opinions.
Survivors include a son, Kevin Kiso, grandson Aleister Kiso, sisters Susan (Dustin) Frederick of Bothell and Margery Kiso of Puyallup, stepbrother Fred Steinaway of Ottumwa, IA, as well as nieces, grandnieces and nephews, and cousins. Tom was truly loved and respected by his many friends and will be deeply missed.
There will be a celebration of Tom's life at the Mineral Lake Event Center (the old Mineral Grade School) in Mineral, WA, on Sunday, April 17th at 1 p.m. Donations in Tom's name may be made to your favorite charity. Online memorial at www.rill.com.
Colonel David Simpson
of Paso Robles, CA
Feb. 6, 1943
to March 25, 2011
On Friday, March 25, 2011, Colonel David Simpson died at his home in Paso Robles, Calif.
He was born in Port Gamble, Wash., in February 1943. David graduated from West High School in Bremerton, Wash., on June 19, 1961, and Pacific University in Forest Grove, Ore., on December 19, 1965.
After graduation, he joined the U.S. Army on December 22, 1966. He then joined the U.S. Air Force in 1971 and retired as a full Air Force Colonel in January 1993. He had been stationed all over the world including Germany, Spain and Japan and made many close friends that are as close as Paso Robles to as far as Dusseldorf, Germany. He was active as the executive director of the Armed Forces Optometric Society (AFOS).
Dave enjoyed many activities with his wife, family and friends and was a longtime member of the Lions Club and a member of the Clipper Club. At 68 years, his life was too short, but had been very full. There has never been a more caring and devoted husband, father, brother, cousin and grandfather.
Dave is survived by his wife, Andrea Simpson; children Sean Simpson and Heidi Kennedy; three grandchildren Aiden Simpson, Joshua Simpson and Zack Kennedy; sister, Barbara Simpson; and cousin, Joseph Padgett. He was preceded in death by his parents, Claude and Marie Simpson.
A gathering will be held Friday, April 1 from noon to 4 p.m., with Military Honors at noon, at Kuehl-Nicolay Funeral Chapel, 1703 Spring St. in Paso Robles, Calif. Immediately following, there will be a gathering at the family home. Dave's family asks that friends and family consider sending flowers to the visitation or making a donation to the Lion's Club.
Charlotte MacVane
of Bainbridge Island
Dec. 6, 1929
to March 26, 2011
Charlotte MacVane, beloved wife of Tom, died peacefully at home in his arms on March 26, 2011 after a long struggle with Lyme disease.
Born Charlotte Jane Sears on December 6, 1929 in Boston to Charles and Helen Sears, she grew up in Somerville, Massachusetts. Charlotte graduated in 1951 from Wheelock College in Boston with a degree in elementary education. She taught kindergarten in Medford, Massachusetts and early childhood development at the University of Maryland.
While summering with friends in 1953, Charlotte met her future husband Tom MacVane in his hometown of Long Island, a small island off the Maine coast. They were married on March 5, 1954. Throughout their 57-year marriage, they enjoyed many happy summers in their Long Island cottage The Camp. Charlotte and Tom raised 5 children while living in Maine, New York, California, Indiana and Washington. They spent the past 36 years in their home on Bainbridge Island.
She loved reading and singing to her grandchildren, driving adventures with her husband, walking the paths of Long Island, baking goodies and chatting with family and friends. Charlotte spent many hours volunteering at church, her children's schools, the Long Island Library and was a member of P.E.O. As a new and cautious driver at age 47, her children marveled at her ability to get to her destination without making any left turns! She dedicated her life to the care of her family and they were her joy and contentment. Her love, laughter, smile and wisdom are deeply missed.
Charlotte is survived by her husband Tom, daughters Ellen Arbour (Ron), Susan Armstrong (Vince), Beth Brundige (Mike) all of Bainbridge Island; sons Todd of Bainbridge Island and Jay (Heather) of Poulsbo and grandchildren Kyle, Scott, Grace (Alex), Dane, Lance, Ty, Troy, Cole, Emma and Cara. She was preceded in death by her parents and her sister, Marion.
A private memorial will be held on Bainbridge Island and an additional service is planned this summer on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, donations are suggested to the International Lyme and Associated Diseases Society at www.ilads.org.
It is our hope that others will learn about Lyme disease, a disease easily misdiagnosed.
Please sign the online guest book at www.CookFamilyFuneralHome.com.
